title: Indianapolis
text:
Indianapolis (), colloquially known as Indy, is the <a href="List%20of%20U.S.%20state%20and%20territorial%20capitals">state capital</a> and <a href="List%20of%20U.S.%20states%27%20largest%20cities%20by%20population">most-populous city</a> of the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a> and the <a href="county%20seat">seat</a> of <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Marion County</a>. According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the consolidated population of Indianapolis and Marion County in 2020 was 977,642. The "<a href="Indianapolis%20%28balance%29">balance</a>" population, which excludes semi-autonomous municipalities in Marion County, was 887,642. It is the <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20cities%20by%20population">15th most populous</a> city in the U.S., the third-most populous city in the <a href="Midwestern%20United%20States">Midwest</a>, after <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a> and <a href="Columbus%2C%20Ohio">Columbus, Ohio</a>, and the fourth-most populous state capital after <a href="Phoenix%2C%20Arizona">Phoenix, Arizona</a>; <a href="Austin%2C%20Texas">Austin, Texas</a>; and Columbus. The <a href="Indianapolis%20metropolitan%20area">Indianapolis metropolitan area</a> is the <a href="List%20of%20Metropolitan%20Statistical%20Areas">33rd most populous</a> <a href="metropolitan%20statistical%20area">metropolitan statistical area</a> in the U.S., with 2,048,703 residents. Its <a href="Combined%20statistical%20area">combined statistical area ranks 28th</a>, with a population of 2,431,361. Indianapolis covers , making it the <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20cities%20by%20area">18th largest city by land area</a> in the U.S.
<a href="Indigenous%20peoples%20of%20the%20Americas">Indigenous peoples</a> inhabited the area dating to as early as 10,000 BC. In 1818, the <a href="Lenape">Delaware</a> relinquished their tribal lands in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20St.%20Mary%27s">Treaty of St. Mary's</a>. In 1821, Indianapolis was founded as a <a href="planned%20city">planned city</a> for the new seat of Indiana's state government. The city was <a href="plat">plat</a>ted by <a href="Alexander%20Ralston">Alexander Ralston</a> and <a href="Elias%20Pym%20Fordham">Elias Pym Fordham</a> on a grid next to the <a href="White%20River%20%28Indiana%29">White River</a>. Completion of the <a href="National%20Road">National</a> and <a href="Michigan%20Road">Michigan</a> roads and arrival of rail later solidified the city's position as a manufacturing and transportation hub. Two of the city's nicknames reflect its historical ties to transportation—the "<a href="Crossroads%20of%20America">Crossroads of America</a>" and "Railroad City". Since the 1970 <a href="city-county%20consolidation">city-county consolidation</a>, known as <a href="Unigov">Unigov</a>, local government administration operates under the direction of an elected 25-member <a href="Indianapolis%20City-County%20Council">city-county council</a> headed by the <a href="List%20of%20mayors%20of%20Indianapolis">mayor</a>.
Indianapolis anchors the <a href="List%20of%20U.S.%20metropolitan%20areas%20by%20GDP">29th largest economic region</a> in the U.S., based primarily on the sectors of finance and insurance, manufacturing, professional and business services, education and health care, government, and wholesale trade. The city has notable <a href="niche%20market">niche market</a>s in <a href="amateur%20sports">amateur sports</a> and <a href="auto%20racing">auto racing</a>. The city is home to three <a href="Fortune%20500">"Fortune" 500</a> companies, two major league sports clubs, four university campuses, and several museums, including <a href="The%20Children%27s%20Museum%20of%20Indianapolis">the world's largest children's museum</a>. However, the city is perhaps best known for annually hosting the world's largest single-day sporting event, the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>. Among the city's <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places%20listings%20in%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">historic sites and districts</a>, Indianapolis is home to the largest collection of monuments dedicated to veterans and war casualties in the U.S. outside of <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>
History.
Etymology.
The name Indianapolis is derived from the state's name, Indiana (meaning "Land of the Indians", or simply "Indian Land"), and "", the <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> word for "city." <a href="Jeremiah%20Sullivan">Jeremiah Sullivan</a>, justice of the <a href="Indiana%20Supreme%20Court">Indiana Supreme Court</a>, is credited with coining the name. Other names considered were Concord, Suwarrow, and <a href="Tecumseh">Tecumseh</a>.
Founding.
In 1816, the year Indiana gained statehood, the <a href="U.S.%20Congress">U.S. Congress</a> donated four sections of federal land to establish a permanent seat of state government. Two years later, under the <a href="Treaty%20of%20St.%20Mary%27s">Treaty of St. Mary's</a> (1818), the <a href="Lenape">Delaware</a> relinquished title to their tribal lands in central Indiana, agreeing to leave the area by 1821. This tract of land, which was called the <a href="New%20Purchase%20%281818%29">New Purchase</a>, included the site selected for the new state capital in 1820. The indigenous people of the land prior to <a href="Indian%20removals%20in%20Indiana">systematic removal</a> are the <a href="Miami%20Nation%20of%20Indiana">Miami Nation of Indiana</a> (<a href="Miami%20Nation%20of%20Oklahoma">Miami Nation of Oklahoma</a>) and Indianapolis makes up part of Cession 99; the primary treaty between the indigenous population and the United States was the <a href="Treaty%20of%20St.%20Mary%27s%20%281818%29">Treaty of St. Mary's (1818)</a>.
The availability of new federal lands for purchase in central Indiana attracted settlers, many of them descendants of families from northwestern Europe. Although many of these first European and American settlers were <a href="Protestants">Protestants</a>, a large proportion of the early <a href="Irish%20people">Irish</a> and <a href="Germans">German</a> immigrants were <a href="Catholics">Catholics</a>. Few <a href="African%20American">African American</a>s lived in central Indiana before 1840. The first <a href="European%20American">European American</a>s to permanently settle in the area that became Indianapolis were either the McCormick or Pogue families. The McCormicks are generally considered to be the first permanent settlers; however, some historians believe <a href="George%20Pogue">George Pogue</a> and family may have arrived first, on March 2, 1819, and settled in a log cabin along the creek that was later called <a href="Pogue%27s%20Run">Pogue's Run</a>. Other historians have argued as early as 1822 that <a href="John%20Wesley%20McCormick">John Wesley McCormick</a>, his family, and employees became the area's first European American settlers, settling near the <a href="White%20River%20%28Indiana%29">White River</a> in February 1820.
On January 11, 1820, the <a href="Indiana%20General%20Assembly">Indiana General Assembly</a> authorized a committee to select a site in central Indiana for the new state capital. The state legislature approved the site, adopting the name Indianapolis on January 6, 1821. In April, <a href="Alexander%20Ralston">Alexander Ralston</a> and <a href="Elias%20Pym%20Fordham">Elias Pym Fordham</a> were appointed to survey and design a town plan for the new settlement. Indianapolis became a seat of county government on December 31, 1821, when <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Marion County</a>, was established. A combined county and town government continued until 1832 when Indianapolis was incorporated as a town. Indianapolis became an incorporated city effective March 30, 1847. <a href="Samuel%20Henderson%20%28Indianapolis%20mayor%29">Samuel Henderson</a>, the city's first mayor, led the new city government, which included a seven-member city council. In 1853, voters approved a new city charter that provided for an elected mayor and a fourteen-member city council. The city charter continued to be revised as Indianapolis expanded. Effective January 1, 1825, the seat of state government moved to Indianapolis from <a href="Corydon%2C%20Indiana">Corydon, Indiana</a>. In addition to state government offices, a <a href="United%20States%20district%20court">U.S. district court</a> was established at Indianapolis in 1825.
Growth occurred with the opening of the <a href="National%20Road">National Road</a> through the town in 1827, the first major federally funded highway in the United States. A small segment of the ultimately failed <a href="Indiana%20Central%20Canal">Indiana Central Canal</a> was opened in 1839. The first railroad to serve Indianapolis, the <a href="Jeffersonville%2C%20Madison%20and%20Indianapolis%20Railroad">Jeffersonville, Madison and Indianapolis Railroad</a>, began operation in 1847, and subsequent railroad connections fostered growth. <a href="Indianapolis%20Union%20Station">Indianapolis Union Station</a> was the first of its kind in the world when it opened in 1853.
Civil War and Gilded Age.
During the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, Indianapolis was mostly loyal to the <a href="Union%20%28American%20Civil%20War%29">Union</a> cause. <a href="Governor%20of%20Indiana">Governor</a> <a href="Oliver%20P.%20Morton">Oliver P. Morton</a>, a major supporter of <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Abraham%20Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>, quickly made Indianapolis a rallying place for <a href="Union%20Army">Union army</a> troops. On February 11, 1861, <a href="President-elect%20of%20the%20United%20States">President-elect</a> Lincoln arrived in the city, en route to <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> for his <a href="First%20inauguration%20of%20Abraham%20Lincoln">presidential inauguration</a>, marking the first visit from a president-elect in the city's history. On April 16, 1861, the first orders were issued to form Indiana's first regiments and establish Indianapolis as a headquarters for the state's volunteer soldiers. Within a week, more than 12,000 recruits signed up to fight for the Union.
Indianapolis became a major logistics hub during the war, establishing the city as a crucial military base. Between 1860 and 1870, the city's population more than doubled. An estimated 4,000 men from Indianapolis served in 39 regiments, and an estimated 700 died during the war. On May 20, 1863, Union soldiers attempted to disrupt a statewide Democratic convention at Indianapolis, forcing the proceedings to be adjourned, sarcastically referred to as the <a href="Battle%20of%20Pogue%27s%20Run">Battle of Pogue's Run</a>. Fear turned to panic in July 1863, during <a href="Morgan%27s%20Raid">Morgan's Raid</a> into southern Indiana, but Confederate forces turned east toward <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>, never reaching Indianapolis. On April 30, 1865, Lincoln's funeral train made a stop at Indianapolis, where an estimated crowd of more than 100,000 people passed the assassinated president's <a href="bier">bier</a> at the <a href="Indiana%20Statehouse">Indiana Statehouse</a>.
Following the Civil War—and in the wake of the <a href="Second%20Industrial%20Revolution">Second Industrial Revolution</a>—Indianapolis experienced tremendous growth and prosperity. In 1880, Indianapolis was the world's third largest pork packing city, after <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a> and <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a>, and the second largest railroad center in the United States by 1888. By 1890, the city's population surpassed 100,000. Some of the city's most notable businesses were founded during this period of growth and innovation, including <a href="L.%20S.%20Ayres">L. S. Ayres</a> (1872), <a href="Eli%20Lilly%20and%20Company">Eli Lilly and Company</a> (1876), <a href="Madam%20C.%20J.%20Walker%20Manufacturing%20Company">Madam C. J. Walker Manufacturing Company</a> (1910), and <a href="Allison%20Transmission">Allison Transmission</a> (1915). Once home to 60 automakers, Indianapolis rivaled <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> as a center of automobile manufacturing. The city was an early focus of <a href="labor%20organization">labor organization</a>. The <a href="Indianapolis%20Street%20Car%20Strike%20of%201913">Indianapolis Street Car Strike of 1913</a> and subsequent police mutiny and riots led to the creation of the state's earliest labor-protection laws, including a <a href="minimum%20wage">minimum wage</a>, regular work weeks, and improved working conditions. The <a href="International%20Typographical%20Union">International Typographical Union</a> and <a href="United%20Mine%20Workers%20of%20America">United Mine Workers of America</a> were among several influential labor unions based in the city.
Progressive Era to World War II.
Some of the city's most prominent architectural features and best known historical events date from the turn of the 20th century. The <a href="Soldiers%27%20and%20Sailors%27%20Monument%20%28Indianapolis%29">Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument</a>, dedicated on May 15, 1902, would later become the city's unofficial symbol. <a href="Ray%20Harroun">Ray Harroun</a> won the inaugural running of the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>, held May 30, <a href="1911%20Indianapolis%20500">1911</a>, at <a href="Indianapolis%20Motor%20Speedway">Indianapolis Motor Speedway</a>. Indianapolis was one of the hardest hit cities in the <a href="Great%20Flood%20of%201913">Great Flood of 1913</a>, resulting in five known deaths and the displacement of 7,000 families.
Post–World War II.
As a stop on the <a href="Underground%20Railroad">Underground Railroad</a>, Indianapolis had one of the largest black populations in the <a href="Union%20%28American%20Civil%20War%29">Northern States</a>, until the <a href="Great%20Migration%20%28African%20American%29">Great Migration</a>. Led by <a href="D.%20C.%20Stephenson">D. C. Stephenson</a>, the <a href="Indiana%20Klan">Indiana Klan</a> became the most powerful political and social organization in Indianapolis from 1921 through 1928, controlling City Council and the Board of School Commissioners, among others. At its height, more than 40% of native-born white males in Indianapolis claimed membership in the Klan. While campaigning in the city in 1968, <a href="Robert%20F.%20Kennedy">Robert F. Kennedy</a> delivered one of the most lauded <a href="Robert%20F.%20Kennedy%27s%20speech%20on%20the%20assassination%20of%20Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.">speeches</a> in 20th century American history, following the assassination of civil rights leader <a href="Martin%20Luther%20King%20Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a> As in most U.S. cities during the <a href="Civil%20Rights%20Movement">Civil Rights Movement</a>, the city experienced strained race relations. A 1971 federal court decision forcing <a href="Indianapolis%20Public%20Schools">Indianapolis Public Schools</a> to implement <a href="desegregation%20busing">desegregation busing</a> proved controversial.
Under the mayoral administration of <a href="Richard%20Lugar">Richard Lugar</a>, the city and county governments restructured, consolidating most public services into a new entity called <a href="Unigov">Unigov</a>. The plan removed bureaucratic redundancies, captured increasingly <a href="suburbanization">suburbanizing</a> tax revenue, and created a <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> <a href="political%20machine">political machine</a> that dominated Indianapolis politics until the 2000s. Unigov went into effect on January 1, 1970, increasing the city's land area by and population by 268,366 people. It was the first major city-county consolidation to occur in the United States without a <a href="referendum">referendum</a> since the creation of the <a href="City%20of%20Greater%20New%20York">City of Greater New York</a> in 1898.
Amid the changes in government and growth, the city invested in an aggressive strategy to brand Indianapolis as a <a href="sports%20tourism">sports tourism</a> destination, known as the Indianapolis Project. Under the administration of the city's longest-serving mayor, <a href="William%20Hudnut">William Hudnut</a> (1976–1992), millions of dollars were poured into sport facilities and public relations campaigns as part of an economic development strategy. The strategy was successful in landing the <a href="U.S.%20Olympic%20Festival">U.S. Olympic Festival</a> in 1983, securing the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts%20relocation%20to%20Indianapolis">1984 relocation</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> <a href="Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>, and hosting the <a href="1987%20Pan%20American%20Games">1987 Pan American Games</a>.
Modern Indianapolis.
Economic development initiatives focused on revitalizing the city's downtown continued in the 1990s under the mayoral administration of <a href="Stephen%20Goldsmith">Stephen Goldsmith</a>. During this period, a number of cultural amenities were completed at <a href="White%20River%20State%20Park">White River State Park</a>, the <a href="Indiana%20Central%20Canal">Canal Walk</a> continued development, <a href="Circle%20Centre%20Mall">Circle Centre Mall</a> was completed, and new sports venues (<a href="Victory%20Field">Victory Field</a> and Conseco Fieldhouse, now <a href="Gainbridge%20Fieldhouse">Gainbridge Fieldhouse</a>) were opened. In 1999, several <a href="Indianapolis%20Cultural%20Districts">cultural districts</a> were designated to capitalize on cultural assets within historically significant neighborhoods unique to the city's heritage as a means to promote continued economic development.
During the 2000s, the city invested heavily in infrastructure projects, including two of the largest building projects in the city's history: the $1.1 billion <a href="Indianapolis%20International%20Airport">Indianapolis International Airport</a> Colonel H. Weir Cook Terminal and $720 million <a href="Lucas%20Oil%20Stadium">Lucas Oil Stadium</a>, both opened in 2008. A $275 million expansion of the <a href="Indiana%20Convention%20Center">Indiana Convention Center</a> was completed in 2011. Construction began that year on DigIndy, a $1.9 billion project to correct the city's <a href="Combined%20sewer%23Combined%20sewer%20overflows%20%28CSOs%29">combined sewer overflows</a> by 2025. Rapid transit was reintroduced to Indianapolis with the opening of <a href="IndyGo">IndyGo</a>'s $96 million <a href="Red%20Line%20%28IndyGo%29">Red Line</a> <a href="bus%20rapid%20transit">bus rapid transit</a> project in 2019.
Geography and environment.
Indianapolis is located in the <a href="East%20North%20Central%20States">East North Central</a> region of the <a href="Midwestern%20United%20States">Midwestern United States</a>, in <a href="central%20Indiana">central Indiana</a>. According to the <a href="U.S.%20Census%20Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, the <a href="Indianapolis%20%28balance%29">Indianapolis (balance)</a> encompasses a total area of , of which is land and is water. Indianapolis is the <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20cities%20by%20area">18th largest city by land area</a> in the U.S. The consolidated city boundaries are coterminous with <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Marion County</a>, with the exception of the autonomous municipalities of <a href="Beech%20Grove%2C%20Indiana">Beech Grove</a>, <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Indiana">Lawrence</a>, <a href="Southport%2C%20Indiana">Southport</a>, and <a href="Speedway%2C%20Indiana">Speedway</a>. Nine <a href="civil%20township">townships</a> form the broadest geographic divisions within the city and county.
Topography.
Indianapolis is within the Tipton Till Plain, a flat to gently sloping terrain underlain by glacial deposits known as <a href="till">till</a>. The lowest point in the city is about <a href="above%20mean%20sea%20level">above mean sea level</a>, with the highest natural elevation at about above sea level. Few hills or short <a href="ridge">ridge</a>s, known as <a href="kame">kame</a>s, rise about to above the surrounding terrain. The city lies just north of the <a href="Indiana%20Uplands">Indiana Uplands</a>, a region characterized by rolling hills and high <a href="limestone">limestone</a> content.
Topographic relief slopes gently toward the <a href="White%20River%20%28Indiana%29">White River</a> and its two primary tributaries, <a href="Fall%20Creek%20%28Indiana%29">Fall</a> and Eagle creeks. In total, there are about 35 streams in the city, including <a href="Indian%20Creek%20%28Fall%20Creek%29">Indian Creek</a> and <a href="Pogue%27s%20Run">Pogue's Run</a>. The city's largest waterbodies are artificial <a href="quarry%20lake">quarry lake</a>s or <a href="reservoir">reservoir</a>s.
Ecology.
Indianapolis is situated in the <a href="Southern%20Great%20Lakes%20forests">Southern Great Lakes forests</a> <a href="ecoregion">ecoregion</a> which in turn is located within the larger <a href="temperate%20broadleaf%20and%20mixed%20forests">temperate broadleaf and mixed forests</a> <a href="biome">biome</a>, as defined by the <a href="World%20Wide%20Fund%20for%20Nature">World Wide Fund for Nature</a>. Based on the <a href="United%20States%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">United States Environmental Protection Agency</a>'s <a href="List%20of%20ecoregions%20in%20Indiana">alternative classification system</a>, the city is located in the <a href="Corn%20Belt">Eastern Corn Belt Plains</a>, an area of the U.S. known for its fertile agricultural land.
Much of the <a href="decidious">decidious</a> forests that once covered the region were <a href="deforestation">cleared</a> for agricultural land and <a href="urban%20sprawl">urban development</a>, contributing to considerable <a href="habitat%20destruction">habitat loss</a>. Indianapolis's current urban tree canopy averages approximately 33%. A rare example of <a href="old-growth%20forest">old-growth forest</a> in the city can be found on of <a href="Crown%20Hill%20Cemetery">Crown Hill Cemetery</a>'s North Woods in the <a href="Butler%E2%80%93Tarkington%2C%20Indianapolis">Butler–Tarkington</a> neighborhood. The cemetery's represents the largest green space in <a href="Center%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Center Township</a>, home to an abundance of wildlife and some 130 species of trees. Native trees most common to the area include varieties of <a href="Fraxinus">ash</a>, <a href="maple">maple</a>, and <a href="oak">oak</a>. Several <a href="invasive%20species">invasive species</a> are also common in Indianapolis, including <a href="Ailanthus%20altissima">tree of heaven</a>, <a href="Euonymus%20fortunei">wintercreeper</a>, <a href="Lonicera%20maackii">Amur honeysuckle</a>, and <a href="Pyrus%20calleryana">Callery or Bradford pear</a>.
Wildlife common to the Indianapolis area include <a href="mammal">mammal</a>s such as the <a href="white-tailed%20deer">white-tailed deer</a>, <a href="red%20fox">red fox</a>, <a href="eastern%20chipmunk">eastern chipmunk</a>, <a href="eastern%20cottontail">eastern cottontail</a>, and the <a href="eastern%20gray%20squirrel">eastern grey</a> and <a href="American%20red%20squirrel">American red squirrel</a>s. In recent years, local <a href="raccoon">raccoon</a> and <a href="groundhog">groundhog</a> populations have increased alongside rare sightings of <a href="American%20badger">American badger</a>s and <a href="coyote">coyote</a>s. Birds native to the area include the <a href="northern%20cardinal">northern cardinal</a>, <a href="wood%20thrush">wood thrush</a>, <a href="eastern%20screech%20owl">eastern screech owl</a>, <a href="mourning%20dove">mourning dove</a>, <a href="pileated%20woodpecker">pileated</a> and <a href="red-bellied%20woodpecker">red-bellied woodpecker</a>s, and <a href="wild%20turkey">wild turkey</a>. Some 57 species of fish can be found in the city's waterways, including <a href="bass%20%28fish%29">bass</a> and <a href="Centrarchidae">sunfish</a>. Some federally-designated <a href="endangered%20species">endangered</a> and <a href="threatened%20species">threatened species</a> are native to the Indianapolis area, including several species of freshwater <a href="mussel">mussel</a>s, the <a href="Bombus%20affinis">rusty patched bumble bee</a>, <a href="Indiana%20bat">Indiana bat</a>, <a href="Myotis%20septentrionalis">northern long-eared bat</a>, and the <a href="Trifolium%20stoloniferum">running buffalo clover</a>.
Climate.
Indianapolis has a <a href="hot-summer%20humid%20continental%20climate">hot-summer humid continental climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> "Dfa"), but can be considered a borderline <a href="humid%20subtropical%20climate">humid subtropical climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a>: "Cfa") using the isotherm. It experiences four distinct seasons. The city is in <a href="Hardiness%20zone%23United%20States%20hardiness%20zones">USDA hardiness zone</a> 6a.
Typically, summers are hot, humid, and wet. Winters are generally cold with moderate snowfall. The July daily average temperature is . High temperatures reach or exceed an average of 18 days each year, and occasionally exceed . Spring and autumn are usually pleasant, if at times unpredictable; midday temperature drops exceeding are common during March and April, and instances of very warm days () followed within 36 hours by snowfall are not unusual during these months. Winters are cold, with an average January temperature of . Temperatures dip to or below an average of 4.7 nights per year.
The rainiest months occur in the spring and summer, with slightly higher averages during May, June, and July. May is typically the wettest, with an average of of precipitation. Most rain is derived from thunderstorm activity; there is no distinct dry season, although occasional droughts occur. Severe weather is not uncommon, particularly in the spring and summer months; the city experiences an average of 20 thunderstorm days annually.
The city's average annual precipitation is , with snowfall averaging per season. Official temperature extremes range from , set on <a href="1936%20North%20American%20heat%20wave">July 14, 1936</a>, to , set on <a href="1994%20North%20American%20cold%20wave">January 19, 1994</a>.
Cityscape.
Indianapolis is a <a href="planned%20city">planned city</a>. On January 11, 1820, the <a href="Indiana%20General%20Assembly">Indiana General Assembly</a> authorized a committee to select a site in central Indiana for the new state capital, appointing <a href="Alexander%20Ralston">Alexander Ralston</a> and <a href="Elias%20Pym%20Fordham">Elias Pym Fordham</a> to survey and design a town plan for Indianapolis. Ralston had been a surveyor for the French architect <a href="Pierre%20L%27Enfant">Pierre L'Enfant</a>, assisting him with the <a href="L%27Enfant%20Plan">plan for Washington, D.C.</a> Ralston's original plan for Indianapolis called for a town of , near the <a href="confluence">confluence</a> of the <a href="White%20River%20%28Indiana%29">White River</a> and <a href="Fall%20Creek%20%28Indiana%29">Fall Creek</a>.
The plan, known as the <a href="Downtown%20Indianapolis">Mile Square</a>, is bounded by East, West, North, and South streets, centered on a <a href="traffic%20circle">traffic circle</a>, called Monument Circle (originally Governor's Circle), from which Indianapolis's "Circle City" nickname originated. Four diagonal streets radiated a block from Monument Circle: <a href="Massachusetts%20Avenue%2C%20Indianapolis">Massachusetts</a>, Virginia, Kentucky, and <a href="Indiana%20Avenue">Indiana</a> avenues. The city's address numbering system begins at the intersection of <a href="Washington%20Street%20%28Indianapolis%29">Washington</a> and <a href="Meridian%20Street%20%28Indianapolis%29">Meridian</a> streets. Before its submersion into a sanitary tunnel, <a href="Pogue%27s%20Run">Pogue's Run</a> was included into the plan, disrupting the rectilinear street grid to the southeast.
Compared with similar-sized American cities, Indianapolis is unique in that it contains some 200 farms covering thousands of acres of agricultural land within its municipal boundaries. Equestrian farms and corn and soybean fields interspersed with suburban development are commonplace on the city's periphery, especially in <a href="Franklin%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Franklin Township</a>.
Architecture.
Noted as one of the finest examples of the <a href="City%20Beautiful%20movement">City Beautiful movement</a> design in the U.S., the <a href="Indiana%20World%20War%20Memorial%20Plaza">Indiana World War Memorial Plaza Historic District</a> began construction in 1921 in downtown Indianapolis. The district, a <a href="National%20Historic%20Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a>, encompasses several examples of <a href="neoclassical%20architecture">neoclassical architecture</a>, including the <a href="American%20Legion">American Legion</a>, <a href="Indianapolis%20Public%20Library%23Central%20Library">Central Library</a>, and <a href="Birch%20Bayh%20Federal%20Building%20and%20United%20States%20Courthouse">Birch Bayh Federal Building and United States Courthouse</a>. The district is also home to several sculptures and memorials, "<a href="Depew%20Memorial%20Fountain">Depew Memorial Fountain</a>", and open space, hosting many annual civic events.
After completion of the <a href="Soldiers%27%20and%20Sailors%27%20Monument%20%28Indianapolis%29">Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument</a>, an ordinance was passed in 1905 <a href="Height%20restriction%20laws">restricting building heights</a> on the traffic circle to to protect views of the monument. The ordinance was revised in 1922, permitting buildings to rise to , with an additional allowable with a series of <a href="setback%20%28architecture%29">setback</a>s. A citywide height restriction ordinance was instituted in 1912, barring structures over . Completed in 1962, the <a href="City-County%20Building%20%28Indianapolis%29">City-County Building</a> was the first skyscraper in the city, surpassing the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument in height by nearly . A <a href="building%20boom">building boom</a>, lasting from 1982 to 1990, saw the construction of six of the city's ten tallest buildings. The tallest is <a href="Salesforce%20Tower%20%28Indianapolis%29">Salesforce Tower</a>, completed in 1990 at . <a href="Indiana%20limestone">Indiana limestone</a> is the signature building material in Indianapolis, widely included in the city's many monuments, churches, academic, government, and civic buildings.
Neighborhoods.
For statistical purposes, the consolidated city-county is organized into 99 "neighborhood areas" with most containing numerous individual historic and cultural districts, subdivisions, and some semi-autonomous towns. In total, some 500 self-identified neighborhood associations are registered in the City’s Registered Community Organization system. As a result of the city's expansive land area, Indianapolis has a unique <a href="Transect%20%28urban%29">urban-to-rural transect</a>, ranging from dense urban neighborhoods to suburban <a href="tract%20housing">tract housing</a> subdivisions, to rural villages.
Typical of American cities in the Midwest, Indianapolis urbanized in the late-19th and early-20th centuries, resulting in the development of relatively dense, well-defined neighborhoods clustered around streetcar corridors, especially in <a href="Center%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Center Township</a>. Notable <a href="streetcar%20suburb">streetcar suburb</a>s include <a href="Broad%20Ripple%20Village%2C%20Indianapolis">Broad Ripple</a>, <a href="Irvington%20Historic%20District%20%28Indianapolis%2C%20Indiana%29">Irvington</a>, and <a href="University%20Heights%2C%20Indianapolis">University Heights</a>. Starting in the mid-20th century, the <a href="post%E2%80%93World%20War%20II%20economic%20expansion">post–World War II economic expansion</a> and subsequent <a href="suburbanization">suburbanization</a> greatly influenced the city's development patterns. From 1950 to 1970, nearly 100,000 housing units were built in Marion County, most outside Center Township in suburban neighborhoods such as <a href="Castleton%2C%20Indianapolis">Castleton</a>, <a href="Eagledale%2C%20Indianapolis">Eagledale</a>, and <a href="Nora%2C%20Indianapolis">Nora</a>.
Since the 2000s, <a href="Downtown%20Indianapolis">Downtown Indianapolis</a> and surrounding neighborhoods have seen increased reinvestment mirroring nationwide market trends, driven by <a href="empty%20nesters">empty nesters</a> and <a href="millennials">millennials</a>. Renewed interest in urban living has been met with some dispute regarding <a href="gentrification">gentrification</a> and <a href="affordable%20housing">affordable housing</a>. According to a Center for Community Progress report, neighborhoods like <a href="Cottage%20Home%20Historic%20District">Cottage Home</a> and <a href="Fall%20Creek%20Place%2C%20Indianapolis">Fall Creek Place</a> have experienced measurable gentrification since 2000. The <a href="North%20Meridian%20Street%20Historic%20District">North Meridian Street Historic District</a> is among <a href="List%20of%20highest-income%20urban%20neighborhoods%20in%20the%20United%20States">the most affluent urban neighborhoods</a> in the U.S., with a mean <a href="household%20income">household income</a> of $102,599 in 2017.
Parkland.
Indianapolis maintains 212 public parks covering of green space, representing about 5.1% of the city's land area. Amenities include 129 playgrounds, 155 sports fields, of recreational trails, 23 recreation and nature centers, 21 spraygrounds, 19 aquatic centers, 13 golf courses, and four dog parks. The department also provides 2,400 programs and classes annually. <a href="Eagle%20Creek%20Park">Eagle Creek Park</a> is the largest and most visited park in the city and ranks among the <a href="List%20of%20urban%20parks%20by%20size">largest municipal parks in the U.S.</a>, covering .
<a href="Military%20Park%20%28Indianapolis%29">Military Park</a> was established as the city's first state-owned park in 1852. <a href="Garfield%20Park%20%28Indianapolis%29">Garfield Park</a> was the city's first municipally-owned park, opening in 1876 as Southern Park. In the early-20th century, the city enlisted landscape architect <a href="George%20Kessler">George Kessler</a> to conceive a framework for Indianapolis's modern parks system. Kessler's 1909 <a href="Indianapolis%20Park%20and%20Boulevard%20System">Indianapolis Park and Boulevard Plan</a> linked notable parks, such as <a href="Brookside%20Park%20%28Indianapolis%29">Brookside</a>, <a href="Irvington%20Historic%20District%20%28Indianapolis%2C%20Indiana%29%23Parks">Ellenberger</a>, Garfield, and <a href="Riverside%20Park%20%28Indianapolis%29">Riverside</a> parks, with a system of parkways following the city's waterways. The system's were added to the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> in 2003.
Marion County is home to two <a href="List%20of%20Indiana%20state%20parks">Indiana state parks</a>: <a href="Fort%20Harrison%20State%20Park">Fort Harrison State Park</a> in <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Indiana">Lawrence</a> and <a href="White%20River%20State%20Park">White River State Park</a> in downtown Indianapolis. Established in 1996, Fort Harrison State Park covers under the management of the <a href="Indiana%20Department%20of%20Natural%20Resources">Indiana Department of Natural Resources</a>. White River is owned and operated by the White River State Park Development Commission, a quasi-governmental agency. Encompassing , White River is the city's major <a href="urban%20park">urban park</a>, home to the <a href="Indianapolis%20Zoo">Indianapolis Zoo</a>, <a href="White%20River%20Gardens">White River Gardens</a>, and museums. Two <a href="land%20trust">land trust</a>s are active in the city managing several sites for <a href="nature%20conservation">nature conservation</a> throughout the region.
Demographics.
The <a href="U.S.%20Census%20Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a> considers Indianapolis as two entities: the consolidated city and the city's remainder, or <a href="Indianapolis%20%28balance%29">balance</a>. The consolidated city is coterminous with <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Marion County</a>, except the independent municipalities of <a href="Beech%20Grove%2C%20Indiana">Beech Grove</a>, <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Indiana">Lawrence</a>, <a href="Southport%2C%20Indiana">Southport</a>, and <a href="Speedway%2C%20Indiana">Speedway</a>. The city's balance excludes the populations of ten semi-autonomous municipalities that are included in totals for the consolidated city. These are <a href="Clermont%2C%20Indiana">Clermont</a>, <a href="Crows%20Nest%2C%20Indiana">Crows Nest</a>, <a href="Homecroft%2C%20Indiana">Homecroft</a>, <a href="Meridian%20Hills%2C%20Indiana">Meridian Hills</a>, <a href="North%20Crows%20Nest%2C%20Indiana">North Crows Nest</a>, <a href="Rocky%20Ripple%2C%20Indiana">Rocky Ripple</a>, <a href="Spring%20Hill%2C%20Indiana">Spring Hill</a>, <a href="Warren%20Park%2C%20Indiana">Warren Park</a>, <a href="Williams%20Creek%2C%20Indiana">Williams Creek</a>, and <a href="Wynnedale%2C%20Indiana">Wynnedale</a>. An eleventh town, <a href="Cumberland%2C%20Indiana">Cumberland</a>, is partially included. In 2018 estimates, the city's consolidated population was 876,862 and its balance was 867,125. At the 2010 Census, the city's population density was . Indianapolis is the most populous city in Indiana, containing nearly 13% of the state's total population.
The <a href="Indianapolis%20metropolitan%20area">Indianapolis metropolitan area</a>, officially the Indianapolis–Carmel–Anderson metropolitan statistical area (MSA), consists of Marion County and the surrounding counties of <a href="Boone%20County%2C%20Indiana">Boone</a>, <a href="Brown%20County%2C%20Indiana">Brown</a>, <a href="Hamilton%20County%2C%20Indiana">Hamilton</a>, <a href="Hancock%20County%2C%20Indiana">Hancock</a>, <a href="Hendricks%20County%2C%20Indiana">Hendricks</a>, <a href="Johnson%20County%2C%20Indiana">Johnson</a>, <a href="Madison%20County%2C%20Indiana">Madison</a>, <a href="Morgan%20County%2C%20Indiana">Morgan</a>, <a href="Putnam%20County%2C%20Indiana">Putnam</a>, and <a href="Shelby%20County%2C%20Indiana">Shelby</a>. In 2018, the metropolitan area's population was 2,048,703, the most populous in Indiana and home to 30% of the state's residents. With a population of 2,431,361, the larger Indianapolis–Carmel–Muncie combined statistical area (CSA) covers 18 counties, home to 36% of Indiana residents. Indianapolis is also situated within the <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Megalopolis">Great Lakes Megalopolis</a>, the largest of 11 <a href="Megaregions%20of%20the%20United%20States">megaregions</a> in the U.S.
According to the U.S. Census of 2010, 97.2% of the Indianapolis population was reported as one race: 61.8% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 27.5% <a href="African%20American">Black or African American</a>, 2.1% <a href="Asian%20American">Asian</a> (0.4% Burmese, 0.4% Indian, 0.3% Chinese, 0.3% Filipino, 0.1% Korean, 0.1% Vietnamese, 0.1% Japanese, 0.1% Thai, 0.1% other Asian); 0.3% <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">American Indian</a>, and 5.5% as other. The remaining 2.8% of the population was reported as <a href="Multiracial%20American">multiracial</a> (two or more races). The city's <a href="Hispanic%20and%20Latino%20Americans">Hispanic or Latino</a> community comprised 9.4% of the city's population in the 2010 U.S. Census: 6.9% Mexican, 0.4% Puerto Rican, 0.1% Cuban, and 2% as other.
In 2010, the median age for Indianapolis was 33.7 years. Age distribution for the city's inhabitants was 25% under the age of 18; 4.4% were between 18 and 21; 16.3% were age 21 to 65; and 13.1% were age 65 or older. For every 100 females, there were 93 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90 males.
The U.S. Census of 2010 reported 332,199 households in Indianapolis, with an average household size of 2.42 and an average family size of 3.08. Of the total households, 59.3% were family households, with 28.2% of these including the family's own children under the age of 18; 36.5% were husband-wife families; 17.2% had a female householder (with no husband present) and 5.6% had a male householder (with no wife present). The remaining 40.7% were non-family households. , 32% of the non-family households included individuals living alone, 8.3% of these households included individuals age 65 years of age or older.
The U.S. Census Bureau's 2007–2011 <a href="American%20Community%20Survey">American Community Survey</a> indicated the median household income for Indianapolis city was $42,704, and the median family income was $53,161. Median income for males working full-time, year-round, was $42,101, compared to $34,788 for females. Per capita income for the city was $24,430, 14.7% of families and 18.9% of the city's total population living below the poverty line (28.3% were under the age of 18 and 9.2% were age 65 or older).
Based on 2015 estimates, the Indianapolis metropolitan area had the 18th highest percentage of <a href="LGBT">LGBT</a> residents in the U.S., with 4.2% of residents identifying as gay, lesbian, bisexual, or transgender.
In 2015, <a href="Brookings%20Institution">Brookings</a> characterized the Indianapolis metropolitan area as a minor-emerging immigrant gateway with a foreign-born population of 126,767, or 6.4% of the total population, a 131% increase from 2000. Much of this growth can be attributed to thousands of Burmese-Chin refugees who have settled in Indianapolis, particularly <a href="Perry%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Perry Township</a>, since the late-1990s. Indianapolis is home to one of the largest concentrations of <a href="Chin%20people">Chin people</a> outside of <a href="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> (formerly Burma), with an estimated population ranging from 17,000 to 24,000.
Religion.
Of the 42.42% of the city's residents who identify as religious, <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a>s make up the largest group, at 11.31%. The second highest religious group in the city are <a href="Baptist">Baptist</a>s at 10.31%, with <a href="Methodist">Methodist</a>s following behind at 4.97%. <a href="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a>s make up 2.13% of the city's religiously affiliated population, followed by <a href="Pentecostal">Pentecostal</a>s and <a href="Lutheran">Lutheran</a>s. Another 8.57% are affiliated with other Christian faiths. 0.32% of religiously affiliated persons identified themselves as following <a href="Eastern%20religion">Eastern religion</a>s, while 0.68% of the religiously affiliated population identified as <a href="Jewish">Jewish</a>, and 0.29% as <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>. According to the nonpartisan and nonprofit <a href="Public%20Religion%20Research%20Institute">Public Religion Research Institute</a>'s American Values Atlas, 22% of residents identify as religiously "unaffiliated," consistent with the national average of 22.7%.
<a href="Saints%20Peter%20and%20Paul%20Cathedral%20%28Indianapolis%29">SS. Peter and Paul Cathedral</a> is the seat of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Indianapolis">Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Indianapolis</a>. <a href="Bishop%20Simon%20Brut%C3%A9%20College%20Seminary">Bishop Simon Bruté College Seminary</a> and <a href="Marian%20University%20%28Indiana%29">Marian University</a> are affiliated with the archdiocese. <a href="Christian%20Theological%20Seminary">Christian Theological Seminary</a> is another seminary located in the city, affiliated with the <a href="Christian%20Church%20%28Disciples%20of%20Christ%29">Christian Church (Disciples of Christ)</a>. <a href="Christ%20Church%20Cathedral%20%28Indianapolis%29">Christ Church Cathedral</a>, the city's oldest house of worship, is <a href="pro-cathedral">pro-cathedral</a> of the <a href="Episcopal%20Diocese%20of%20Indianapolis">Episcopal Diocese of Indianapolis</a>. The <a href="Indiana-Kentucky%20Synod">Indiana-Kentucky Synod</a> of the <a href="Evangelical%20Lutheran%20Church%20in%20America">Evangelical Lutheran Church in America</a> is also based in Indianapolis. <a href="Religious%20denominations">Religious denominations</a> headquartered in the city include the <a href="Free%20Methodist%20Church">Free Methodist Church</a> and <a href="Lutheran%20Ministerium%20and%20Synod%20%E2%80%93%20USA">Lutheran Ministerium and Synod – USA</a>.
Economy.
In 2015, the <a href="Indianapolis%20metropolitan%20area">Indianapolis metropolitan area</a> had a <a href="gross%20domestic%20product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) of $134 billion. The top industries were: finance, insurance, real estate, rental, and leasing ($30.7B), manufacturing ($30.1B), professional and business services ($14.3B), educational services, health care, and social assistance ($10.8B), and wholesale trade ($8.1B). Government, if it had been a private industry, would have ranked fifth, generating $10.2 billion.
Compared to Indiana as a whole, the Indianapolis metropolitan area has a lower proportion of manufacturing jobs and a higher concentration of jobs in wholesale trade; administrative, support, and waste management; professional, scientific, and technical services; and transportation and warehousing. The city's major exports include <a href="pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, motor vehicle parts, medical equipment and supplies, engine and power equipment, and aircraft products and parts. According to the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Labor%20Statistics">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a>, the region's unemployment rate was 2.8 percent in May 2019.
Three <a href="Fortune%20500">"Fortune" 500</a> companies are based in the city: health insurance company <a href="Anthem%20%28company%29">Anthem</a>; pharmaceutical company <a href="Eli%20Lilly%20and%20Company">Eli Lilly and Company</a>; and <a href="Simon%20Property%20Group">Simon Property Group</a>, the largest <a href="real%20estate%20investment%20trust">real estate investment trust</a> in the U.S. Other companies based in the city include <a href="Allison%20Transmission">Allison Transmission</a>, <a href="Barnes%20%26amp%3B%20Thornburg">Barnes & Thornburg</a>, <a href="Calumet%20Specialty%20Products%20Partners">Calumet Specialty Products Partners</a>, <a href="Duke%20Realty">Duke Realty</a>, <a href="Emmis%20Communications">Emmis Communications</a>, <a href="Finish%20Line%2C%20Inc.">Finish Line, Inc.</a>, <a href="Herff%20Jones">Herff Jones</a>, <a href="Lids%20%28store%29">Lids</a>, <a href="OneAmerica%20Financial%20Partners%2C%20Inc.">OneAmerica Financial Partners, Inc.</a>, <a href="Republic%20Airways%20Holdings">Republic Airways Holdings</a>, and <a href="Steak%20%27n%20Shake">Steak 'n Shake</a>.
Sectors.
Distribution and logistics.
Indianapolis' central location and extensive highway and rail infrastructure have positioned the city as an important logistics center. According to the Indy Chamber, the region was home to some 4,300 establishments employing nearly 110,000 in 2020.
<a href="Amazon%20%28company%29">Amazon</a> has a major presence in the <a href="Indianapolis%20metropolitan%20area">Indianapolis metropolitan area</a>, employing 9,000. Indianapolis is home to <a href="FedEx%20Express">FedEx Express</a>'s National Hub which employs 7,000 workers in sorting, distribution, and shipping at <a href="Indianapolis%20International%20Airport">Indianapolis International Airport</a>. Other logistics companies in the region with large workforces include <a href="Ingram%20Micro">Ingram Micro</a> (1,300) and Venture Logistics (1,150).
Life sciences and health.
Indianapolis anchors one of the largest <a href="List%20of%20life%20sciences">life sciences</a> clusters in the U.S., notably in the subsectors of drugs and pharmaceuticals and agricultural feedstock and chemicals. Life sciences employ between 21,200 and 28,700 among nearly 350 companies located in the region. Pharmaceutical company <a href="Eli%20Lilly%20and%20Company">Eli Lilly</a> is the city's largest private employer, with a workforce of 11,000 in research and development, manufacturing, and executive administration. Other major employers include <a href="Corteva">Corteva Agriscience</a> (1,400), <a href="Labcorp%20Drug%20Development">Labcorp Drug Development</a>, and <a href="Roche">Roche</a>'s North American headquarters (4,500).
Indianapolis is also a hub for academic medicine and health sciences research, home to such institutions as the <a href="Indiana%20Biosciences%20Research%20Institute">Indiana Biosciences Research Institute</a>, <a href="Indiana%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">Indiana University School of Medicine</a>, <a href="Indiana%20University%20School%20of%20Nursing">School of Nursing</a>, and <a href="Indiana%20University%20School%20of%20Dentistry">School of Dentistry</a>; <a href="Marian%20University%20College%20of%20Osteopathic%20Medicine">Marian University College of Osteopathic Medicine</a>; and the <a href="American%20College%20of%20Sports%20Medicine">American College of Sports Medicine</a>. The regional healthcare providers of Community Health Network, <a href="Sidney%20%26amp%3B%20Lois%20Eskenazi%20Hospital">Eskenazi Health</a>, <a href="St.%20Francis%20Hospital%20%26amp%3B%20Health%20Centers">Franciscan Health</a>, <a href="Indiana%20University%20Health">Indiana University Health</a>, and <a href="St.%20Vincent%20Health">St. Vincent Health</a> have a combined workforce of 43,700.
According to a 2021 report commissioned by BioCrossroads, Central Indiana's life sciences and healthcare sector generates nearly $84 billion in total economic output and supports more than 331,000 jobs throughout the region.
Manufacturing.
Historically, manufacturing has been a critical component of Indianapolis' economic landscape; however, <a href="deindustrialization">deindustrialization</a> since the mid-20th century has significantly impacted the city's workforce. Indianapolis is typically considered part of the <a href="Rust%20Belt">Rust Belt</a>, a region of the <a href="Northeastern%20United%20States">Northeastern</a> and <a href="Midwestern%20United%20States">Midwestern</a> U.S. beleaguered by industrial and population decline. Between 1990 and 2012, approximately 26,900 manufacturing jobs were lost in the city as it continued diversification efforts and transitioned to a <a href="service%20economy">service economy</a>. <a href="RCA">RCA</a> and <a href="Western%20Electric">Western Electric</a> formerly employed thousands at their Indianapolis manufacturing plants.
Once home to 60 automakers, Indianapolis rivaled <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> as a center of <a href="automobile%20manufacturing">automobile manufacturing</a> and design in the early-20th century. Indianapolis was home to several <a href="luxury%20car">luxury car</a> companies, including <a href="Duesenberg">Duesenberg</a>, <a href="Marmon%20Motor%20Car%20Company">Marmon</a>, and <a href="Stutz%20Motor%20Company">Stutz Motor Company</a>; however, the automakers did not survive the <a href="Great%20Depression%20in%20the%20United%20States">Great Depression</a> of the 1930s. Detroit's <a href="Big%20Three%20%28automobile%20manufacturers%29">Big Three automakers</a> maintained a presence in the city and continued to operate in various capacities until the 2000s: <a href="Ford%20Motor%20Company">Ford Motor Company</a> (1914–1942, 1956–2008), <a href="Chrysler">Chrysler</a> (1925–2005), and <a href="General%20Motors">General Motors</a> (1930–2011).
Indianapolis is home to <a href="Allison%20Transmission">Allison Transmission</a>'s headquarters and manufacturing facilities, employing 2,500 in design and production of automatic transmissions and hybrid propulsion systems. <a href="Rolls-Royce%20North%20America">Rolls-Royce North America</a> dates its local presence to the establishment of the <a href="Allison%20Engine%20Company">Allison Engine Company</a> in 1915. Its Indianapolis Operations Center has a workforce of 4,000 in aircraft engine development and manufacturing. Other major manufacturing employers include <a href="Allegion">Allegion</a> (1,300) and <a href="Raytheon%20Technologies">Raytheon Technologies</a> (1,000). In 2016, <a href="Carrier%20Corporation">Carrier Corporation</a> <a href="Carrier%20Air%20Conditioner%20move%20to%20Mexico">announced the closure</a> of its Indianapolis plant, moving 1,400 manufacturing jobs to Mexico. Carrier later negotiated with the incoming Trump administration to save some jobs. The company's local workforce numbers 800 in gas furnace production.
Hospitality.
The <a href="hospitality%20industry">hospitality industry</a> is an increasingly vital sector of the Indianapolis economy. According to Visit Indy, 29.2 million visitors generate $5.6 billion annually, supporting 82,900 jobs. Indianapolis has long been a <a href="sports%20tourism">sports tourism</a> destination, but has more recently relied on conventions. From 2010 to 2019, average annual attendance for conventions was 494,000, an increase of 26% from the previous decade.
The <a href="Indiana%20Convention%20Center">Indiana Convention Center</a> (ICC) and <a href="Lucas%20Oil%20Stadium">Lucas Oil Stadium</a> are considered mega convention center facilities, with a combined of exhibition space. ICC is connected to 12 hotels and 4,700 hotel rooms, the most of any U.S. convention center. Resident conventions annually hosted in the city include <a href="FDIC%20International">FDIC International</a>, <a href="National%20FFA%20Organization">National FFA Organization</a> Conference, <a href="Gen%20Con">Gen Con</a>, and <a href="Performance%20Racing%20Industry">Performance Racing Industry</a> (PRI) Trade Show.
Technology.
Indianapolis ranks among the fastest high-tech job growth areas in the U.S. The metropolitan area is home to 28,500 information technology-related jobs at such companies as <a href="Angi">Angi</a>, <a href="Appirio">Appirio</a>, <a href="Formstack">Formstack</a>, <a href="Genesys%20%28company%29">Genesys</a>, <a href="Hubstaff">Hubstaff</a>, <a href="Infosys">Infosys</a>, <a href="Ingram%20Micro">Ingram Micro</a>, and <a href="Salesforce%20Marketing%20Cloud">Salesforce Marketing Cloud</a>. Salesforce has the largest workforce of local tech firms, employing about 2,100 in Indianapolis.
Culture.
Visual arts.
Founded in 1883, the <a href="Indianapolis%20Museum%20of%20Art">Indianapolis Museum of Art</a> (IMA) is the ninth oldest and eighth largest encyclopedic art museum in the U.S. The permanent collection has over 54,000 works, including African, American, Asian, and European pieces. In addition to its collections, the Newfields campus consists of ; <a href="Oldfields">Oldfields</a>, a restored <a href="historic%20house%20museum">house museum</a> and estate once owned by <a href="Josiah%20K.%20Lilly%2C%20Jr.">Josiah K. Lilly, Jr.</a>; and restored gardens and grounds originally designed by Percival Gallagher of the <a href="Olmsted%20Brothers">Olmsted Brothers firm</a>. The IMA also owns the <a href="Miller%20House%20%28Columbus%2C%20Indiana%29">Miller House</a>, a <a href="Mid-century%20modern">Mid-century modern</a> home designed by <a href="Eero%20Saarinen">Eero Saarinen</a> in <a href="Columbus%2C%20Indiana">Columbus, Indiana</a>. The museum's holdings demonstrate the institution's emphasis on the connections among art, design, and the natural environment.
The <a href="Indianapolis%20Art%20Center">Indianapolis Art Center</a>, in <a href="Broad%20Ripple%20Village">Broad Ripple Village</a>, was founded in 1934 by the <a href="Works%20Project%20Administration">Works Project Administration</a>. The center opened at its <a href="Michael%20Graves">Michael Graves</a>-designed building in 1996, including three public art galleries, 11 studios, a library, and auditorium. Opened in 2005, the center's ARTSPARK <a href="sculpture%20garden">sculpture garden</a> covers along the <a href="White%20River%20%28Indiana%29">White River</a>. <a href="Eiteljorg%20Museum%20of%20American%20Indians%20and%20Western%20Art">Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art</a> opened in 1989 at <a href="White%20River%20State%20Park">White River State Park</a> as the only Native American art museum in the Midwest. <a href="Indiana%20University%20%E2%80%93%20Purdue%20University%20Indianapolis">IUPUI</a> contains the <a href="Herron%20School%20of%20Art%20and%20Design">Herron School of Art and Design</a>. Established in 1902, the school's first core faculty included <a href="Impressionist">Impressionist</a> painters of the <a href="Hoosier%20Group">Hoosier Group</a>: <a href="T.%20C.%20Steele">T. C. Steele</a>, <a href="J.%20Ottis%20Adams">J. Ottis Adams</a>, <a href="William%20Forsyth%20%28artist%29">William Forsyth</a>, <a href="Richard%20Gruelle">Richard Gruelle</a>, and <a href="Otto%20Stark">Otto Stark</a>. The university's <a href="Indiana%20University%20%E2%80%93%20Purdue%20University%20Indianapolis%20Public%20Art%20Collection">public art collection</a> is extensive, with more than 30 works. Other public works can be found in the <a href="Eskenazi%20Health%20Art%20Collection">Eskenazi Health Art Collection</a> and the <a href="Indiana%20Statehouse%20Public%20Art%20Collection">Indiana Statehouse Public Art Collection</a>.
Performing arts.
Most of Indianapolis's notable performing arts venues are in the <a href="Massachusetts%20Avenue%2C%20Indianapolis">Mass Ave</a> cultural district and other locations in the <a href="Downtown%20Indianapolis">downtown area</a>. The <a href="Indiana%20Theatre%20%28Indianapolis%2C%20Indiana%29">Indiana Theatre</a> opened as a <a href="movie%20palace">movie palace</a> on <a href="Washington%20Street%20%28Indianapolis%29">Washington Street</a> in 1927 and houses the <a href="Indiana%20Repertory%20Theatre">Indiana Repertory Theatre</a>, a <a href="Regional%20theater%20in%20the%20United%20States">regional</a> <a href="repertory%20theatre">repertory theatre</a>. Located on Monument Circle since 1916, the 1,786-seat <a href="Hilbert%20Circle%20Theatre">Hilbert Circle Theatre</a> is the home of the <a href="Indianapolis%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra</a> (ISO). Founded in 1930, the ISO performed 180 concerts to over 275,000 guests during the 2015–2016 season, generating a record $8.5 million in ticket sales. The <a href="Indianapolis%20Opera">Indianapolis Opera</a>, founded in 1975, maintains a collaborative relationship with the ISO. The nonprofit <a href="Phoenix%20Theatre%20%28Indianapolis%29">Phoenix Theatre</a>, which opened a new Cultural Centre in 2018, focuses on contemporary theatrical productions. TCU Amphitheater at <a href="White%20River%20State%20Park">White River State Park</a> is the city's largest outdoor performing arts venue, with a capacity of 7,500.
In 1927, <a href="Madam%20Walker%20Legacy%20Center">Madam Walker Legacy Center</a> opened in the heart of the city's <a href="African-American%20neighborhood">African-American neighborhood</a> on <a href="Indiana%20Avenue">Indiana Avenue</a>. The theater is named for <a href="Sarah%20Breedlove">Sarah Breedlove</a>, or Madam C. J. Walker, an African American entrepreneur, philanthropist, and activist who began her <a href="Madam%20C.%20J.%20Walker%20Manufacturing%20Company">beauty empire</a> in Indianapolis. Indiana Avenue was home to a notable <a href="jazz">jazz</a> scene from the 1920s through the 1960s, producing greats such as <a href="David%20Baker%20%28composer%29">David Baker</a>, <a href="Slide%20Hampton">Slide Hampton</a>, <a href="Freddie%20Hubbard">Freddie Hubbard</a>, <a href="J.%20J.%20Johnson">J. J. Johnson</a>, <a href="James%20Spaulding">James Spaulding</a>, and the Montgomery Brothers (<a href="Buddy%20Montgomery">Buddy</a>, <a href="Monk%20Montgomery">Monk</a>, and <a href="Wes%20Montgomery">Wes</a>). Wes Montgomery is considered one of the most influential <a href="jazz%20guitarist">jazz guitarist</a>s of all time, and is credited with popularizing the "Naptown Sound."
Mass Ave is home to the <a href="Old%20National%20Centre">Old National Centre</a>, <a href="Athen%C3%A6um%20%28Das%20Deutsche%20Haus%29">Athenæum (Das Deutsche Haus)</a>, The District Theatre, and the Basile and Indy Eleven theaters. Old National Centre at the Murat Shrine is the oldest stage house in Indianapolis, which opened in 1909. The building is a prime example of <a href="Moorish%20Revival%20architecture">Moorish Revival architecture</a> and features a 2,600-seat performing arts theatre, 1,800-seat concert hall, and 600-seat multi-functional room, hosting approximately 300 public and private events throughout the year. The Athenæum, houses the American Cabaret Theater and Young Actors Theater. The 100-seat Basile Theatre and 70-seat <a href="black%20box%20theater">black box</a> Indy Eleven Theatre annually hosts the <a href="Indianapolis%20Theatre%20Fringe%20Festival">Indianapolis Theatre Fringe Festival</a>, nicknamed "IndyFringe," a 10-day showcase of traditional and non-traditional theatre, dance, music, and improvisational performances.
Other notable venues include the <a href="Indianapolis%20Artsgarden">Indianapolis Artsgarden</a>, a performing arts center suspended over the intersection of Washington and Illinois streets, <a href="Clowes%20Memorial%20Hall">Clowes Memorial Hall</a> on the <a href="Butler%20University">Butler University</a> campus, <a href="Melody%20Inn%20%28nightclub%29">Melody Inn</a> in <a href="Butler-Tarkington%2C%20Indianapolis">Butler-Tarkington</a>, <a href="Rivoli%20Theater%20%28Indianapolis%2C%20Indiana%29">Rivoli Theater</a>, The Vogue in <a href="Broad%20Ripple%20Village%2C%20Indianapolis">Broad Ripple</a>, and <a href="The%20Emerson%20Theater">The Emerson Theater</a> in <a href="Little%20Flower%2C%20Indianapolis">Little Flower</a>.
Indianapolis is home to <a href="Bands%20of%20America">Bands of America</a> (BOA), a nationwide organization of high school marching, concert, and jazz bands, and the headquarters for <a href="Drum%20Corps%20International">Drum Corps International</a> (DCI), a professional drum and bugle corps association. Annual music events include the <a href="International%20Violin%20Competition%20of%20Indianapolis">International Violin Competition of Indianapolis</a>, <a href="Midwest%20Music%20Summit">Midwest Music Summit</a>, and <a href="Indy%20Jazz%20Fest">Indy Jazz Fest</a>.
Literature.
Indianapolis was at the center of the <a href="Golden%20Age%20of%20Indiana%20Literature">Golden Age of Indiana Literature</a> from 1870 to 1920. Several notable poets and writers based in the city achieved national prominence and critical acclaim during this period, including <a href="James%20Whitcomb%20Riley">James Whitcomb Riley</a>, <a href="Booth%20Tarkington">Booth Tarkington</a>, and <a href="Meredith%20Nicholson">Meredith Nicholson</a>. In "A History of Indiana Literature", Arthur W. Shumaker remarked on the era's influence: "It was the age of famous men and their famous books. In it Indiana, and particularly Indianapolis, became a literary center which in many ways rivaled the East." A 1947 study found that Indiana authors ranked second to New York in the number of <a href="bestseller">bestseller</a>s produced in the previous 40 years. Located in <a href="Lockerbie%20Square">Lockerbie Square</a>, the <a href="James%20Whitcomb%20Riley%20Museum%20Home">James Whitcomb Riley Museum Home</a> has been a <a href="National%20Historic%20Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> since 1962.
Perhaps the city's most acclaimed twentieth century writer was <a href="Kurt%20Vonnegut">Kurt Vonnegut</a>, known for his darkly satirical and controversial bestselling novel "<a href="Slaughterhouse-Five">Slaughterhouse-Five</a>". The <a href="Kurt%20Vonnegut%20Museum%20and%20Library">Kurt Vonnegut Museum and Library</a> opened in 2010 downtown. Vonnegut became known for including at least one character in his novels from Indianapolis. Upon returning to the city in 1986, Vonnegut acknowledged the influence the city had on his writings:
A key figure of the <a href="Black%20Arts%20Movement">Black Arts Movement</a>, Indianapolis resident <a href="Mari%20Evans">Mari Evans</a> was among the most influential of the twentieth century's black poets. Indianapolis is home to bestselling <a href="young%20adult%20fiction">young adult fiction</a> writer <a href="John%20Green">John Green</a>, known for his critically acclaimed 2012 novel "<a href="The%20Fault%20in%20Our%20Stars">The Fault in Our Stars</a>", set in the city.
Attractions and events.
<a href="The%20Children%27s%20Museum%20of%20Indianapolis">The Children's Museum of Indianapolis</a> is the largest of its kind in the world, offering of exhibit space. The museum holds a collection of over 120,000 artifacts, including the <a href="Broad%20Ripple%20Park%20Carousel">Broad Ripple Park Carousel</a>, a <a href="National%20Historic%20Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a>. Because of its leadership and innovations, the museum is a world leader in its field. "<a href="Child%20%28magazine%29">Child</a>" and "<a href="Parents%20%28magazine%29">Parents</a>" magazine have both ranked the museum as the best children's museum in the U.S. The museum is one of the city's most popular attractions, with 1.2 million visitors in 2014.
The <a href="Indianapolis%20Zoo">Indianapolis Zoo</a> is home to nearly 1,400 animals of 214 species and 31,000 plants, including many threatened and endangered species. The zoo is a leader in animal conservation and research, recognized for its biennial <a href="Indianapolis%20Prize">Indianapolis Prize</a> designation. It is the only American zoo accredited as a zoo, aquarium, and zoological garden by the <a href="Association%20of%20Zoos%20and%20Aquariums">Association of Zoos and Aquariums</a>. It is the largest privately funded zoo in the U.S. and one of the city's most visited attractions, with 1.2 million guests in 2014.
The <a href="Indianapolis%20Motor%20Speedway%20Museum">Indianapolis Motor Speedway Museum</a> exhibits an extensive collection of <a href="auto%20racing">auto racing</a> memorabilia showcasing various motorsports and automotive history. The museum is the permanent home of the <a href="Borg-Warner%20Trophy">Borg-Warner Trophy</a>, presented to <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a> winners. Daily grounds and track tours are also based at the museum. The <a href="NCAA%20Hall%20of%20Champions">NCAA Hall of Champions</a> opened in 2000 at <a href="White%20River%20State%20Park">White River State Park</a> housing collegiate athletic artifacts and interactive exhibits covering all 23 NCAA-sanctioned sports.
Indianapolis is home to several centers commemorating Indiana history. These include the <a href="Indiana%20Historical%20Society">Indiana Historical Society</a>, <a href="Indiana%20State%20Library%20and%20Historical%20Bureau">Indiana State Library and Historical Bureau</a>, <a href="Indiana%20State%20Museum">Indiana State Museum</a>, and <a href="Indiana%20Medical%20History%20Museum">Indiana Medical History Museum</a>. <a href="Indiana%20Landmarks">Indiana Landmarks</a>, the largest private statewide <a href="historic%20preservation">historic preservation</a> organization in the U.S., is also based in the city. The <a href="Benjamin%20Harrison%20Presidential%20Site">Benjamin Harrison Presidential Site</a>, in the <a href="Old%20Northside%20Historic%20District">Old Northside Historic District</a>, is open for daily tours and includes archives and memorabilia from the <a href="Benjamin%20Harrison">23rd President of the United States</a>. President Harrison is buried about north of the site at <a href="Crown%20Hill%20Cemetery">Crown Hill Cemetery</a>, listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>. Other notable graves include three <a href="Vice%20Presidents%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. Vice Presidents</a> and notorious American gangster, <a href="John%20Dillinger">John Dillinger</a>.
Two museums and several memorials in the city commemorate armed forces or conflict, including the Colonel Eli Lilly Civil War Museum at the <a href="Soldiers%27%20and%20Sailors%27%20Monument%20%28Indianapolis%29">Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument</a> and <a href="Indiana%20World%20War%20Memorial%23Indiana%20World%20War%20Memorial%20Military%20Museum">Indiana World War Memorial Military Museum</a> at the <a href="Indiana%20World%20War%20Memorial%20Plaza">Indiana World War Memorial Plaza</a>. Outside of <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, Indianapolis contains the largest collection of monuments dedicated to veterans and war casualties in the nation. Other notable sites are the <a href="Crown%20Hill%20National%20Cemetery">Crown Hill National Cemetery</a>, <a href="Indiana%209/11%20Memorial">Indiana 9/11 Memorial</a>, <a href="Medal%20of%20Honor%20Memorial">Medal of Honor Memorial</a>, and the <a href="USS%20Indianapolis%20%28CA-35%29%23Memorials">USS "Indianapolis" National Memorial</a>.
Nearly of the former <a href="Indiana%20Central%20Canal">Indiana Central Canal</a>—now known as the Canal Walk—link several downtown museums, memorials, and public art pieces. Flanked by walking and bicycling paths, the Canal Walk also offers gondola rides, pedal boat, kayak, and <a href="Surrey%20%28carriage%29">surrey</a> rentals. The Indiana Central Canal has been recognized by the <a href="American%20Water%20Works%20Association">American Water Works Association</a> as an <a href="American%20Water%20Landmark">American Water Landmark</a> since 1971.
Indianapolis is home to dozens of annual festivals and events showcasing local culture. The "<a href="Indianapolis%20500%20traditions%23Month%20of%20May">Month of May</a>" (a series of celebrations leading to the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>) is perhaps the largest annual celebration in the city, with the <a href="500%20Festival%20Parade">500 Festival Parade</a> regularly drawing 300,000 spectators. Other notable events include <a href="Indiana%20Black%20Expo">Indiana Black Expo</a>, <a href="Indiana%20State%20Fair">Indiana State Fair</a>, <a href="Indy%20Pride%20Festival">Indy Pride Festival</a>, and <a href="Historic%20Irvington%20Halloween%20Festival">Historic Irvington Halloween Festival</a>.
Cuisine.
Indianapolis has an emerging food scene as well as established eateries. Founded in 1821 as the city's <a href="Marketplaces%23Types">public market</a>, the <a href="Indianapolis%20City%20Market">Indianapolis City Market</a> has served the community from its current building since 1886. Prior to <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the City Market and neighboring <a href="Tomlinson%20Hall">Tomlinson Hall</a> (since demolished) were home to meat and vegetable vendors. As consumer habits evolved and residents moved from the central city, the City Market transitioned from a traditional marketplace to a <a href="food%20court">food court</a>, a function it retains today.
Situated in the <a href="Corn%20Belt">Corn Belt</a>, Indianapolis has maintained close ties to farming and food production. <a href="Urban%20agriculture">Urban agriculture</a> in the city dates to the 1930s, when non-profit organization <a href="Flanner%20House">Flanner House</a> began teaching Black arrivals how to farm on vacant lots during the <a href="Great%20Migration%20%28African%20American%29">Great Migration</a>. Within a few years, more than 200 families were tending 600 garden plots on nearly of urban land on the city's near north side. Urban agriculture has made a comeback in recent years in an effort to alleviate <a href="food%20deserts">food deserts</a>. According to the city's Office of Sustainability, there were 129 community farms and gardens in 2020. , several <a href="farmers%27%20market">farmers' market</a>s have been established throughout Indianapolis.
Distinctive local dishes include <a href="pork%20tenderloin%20sandwich">pork tenderloin sandwich</a>es and <a href="sugar%20cream%20pie">sugar cream pie</a>, the latter being the unofficial state pie of Indiana. The <a href="beef%20Manhattan">beef Manhattan</a>, invented in Indianapolis, can also be found on restaurant menus throughout the city and region.
Opened in 1902, <a href="St.%20Elmo%20Steak%20House">St. Elmo Steak House</a> is well known for its signature <a href="prawn%20cocktail">shrimp cocktail</a>, named by the <a href="Travel%20Channel">Travel Channel</a> as the "world's spiciest food". In 2012, it was recognized by the <a href="James%20Beard%20Foundation">James Beard Foundation</a> as one of "America's Classics". The <a href="Slippery%20Noodle%20Inn">Slippery Noodle Inn</a>, a <a href="blues">blues</a> bar and restaurant, is the oldest continuously operating tavern in Indiana, having opened in 1850. The <a href="Jazz%20Kitchen">Jazz Kitchen</a>, opened in 1994, was recognized in 2011 by <a href="OpenTable">OpenTable</a> as one of the "top 50 late night dining hotspots" in the U.S.
In 2016, "<a href="Cond%C3%A9%20Nast%20Traveler">Condé Nast Traveler</a>" named Indianapolis the "most underrated food city in the U.S.," while ranking Milktooth as one of the best restaurants in the world. "<a href="Food%20%26amp%3B%20Wine">Food & Wine</a>" called Indianapolis the "rising star of the Midwest," recognizing Milktooth, Rook, Amelia's, and Bluebeard, all in <a href="Fletcher%20Place">Fletcher Place</a>. Several Indianapolis chefs and restaurateurs have been semifinalists in the <a href="James%20Beard%20Foundation%20Award">James Beard Foundation Award</a>s in recent years. <a href="Microbreweries">Microbreweries</a> are quickly becoming a staple in the city, increasing fivefold since 2009. There are now about 50 craft brewers in Indianapolis, with <a href="Sun%20King%20Brewing">Sun King Brewing</a> being the largest.
For some time, Indianapolis was known as the "100 Percent American City" for its racial and ethnic homogeneity. Historically, these factors, as well as low taxes and wages, provided <a href="chain%20restaurant">chain restaurant</a>s a relatively stable market to test dining preferences before expanding nationwide. As a result, the Indianapolis metropolitan area had the highest concentration of chain restaurants per capita of any market in the U.S. in 2008, with one chain restaurant for every 1,459 people—44% higher than the national average. In recent years, immigrants have opened some 800 ethnic restaurants.
Film and television.
Indianapolis natives have left a mark on the entertainment industry, most notably during the <a href="Classical%20Hollywood%20cinema">Classical Hollywood cinema</a> era. <a href="James%20Baskett">James Baskett</a> received an <a href="Academy%20Honorary%20Award">Academy Honorary Award</a> in <a href="20th%20Academy%20Awards">1948</a> for his role in <a href="Walt%20Disney">Walt Disney</a>'s "<a href="Song%20of%20the%20South">Song of the South</a>", becoming the first Black male to receive an Oscar. <a href="Sid%20Grauman">Sid Grauman</a>, one of the founders of the <a href="Academy%20of%20Motion%20Picture%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences</a>, also received an Academy Honorary Award in <a href="20th%20Academy%20Awards">1949</a>, recognized for raising the standard for film exhibition. Perhaps the most famous actor from the Indianapolis area is Academy Award-nominee, <a href="Steve%20McQueen">Steve McQueen</a>, who was born in <a href="Beech%20Grove%2C%20Indiana">Beech Grove</a>. Other Academy Award nominees from the city include costume designer <a href="Gloria%20Gresham">Gloria Gresham</a>, actress <a href="Marjorie%20Main">Marjorie Main</a>, and actor <a href="Clifton%20Webb">Clifton Webb</a>.
The city's storied sports venues have served as a backdrop for such films as "<a href="Hoosiers%20%28film%29">Hoosiers</a>" (1986) and "<a href="Eight%20Men%20Out">Eight Men Out</a>" (1988). The city's largest contribution to <a href="popular%20culture">popular culture</a>, the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>, has influenced entertainment for decades, <a href="Indianapolis%20500%20in%20film%20and%20media">referenced in film, television, video games, and other media</a>. Three motion pictures filmed at the <a href="Indianapolis%20Motor%20Speedway">Indianapolis Motor Speedway</a> include "<a href="Speedway%20%281929%20film%29">Speedway</a>" (1929), "<a href="To%20Please%20a%20Lady">To Please a Lady</a>" (1950), and "<a href="Winning%20%28film%29">Winning</a>" (1969). Other motion pictures at least partially filmed in the city include "<a href="Going%20All%20the%20Way">Going All the Way</a>" (1997), "<a href="Palindromes%20%28film%29">Palindromes</a>" (2004), "<a href="Saving%20Star%20Wars">Saving Star Wars</a>" (2004), "<a href="Amanda%20%282009%20film%29">Amanda</a>" (2009), "<a href="Walter%20%282015%20film%29">Walter</a>" (2015), "<a href="The%20MisEducation%20of%20Bindu">The MisEducation of Bindu</a>" (2019), and "<a href="Athlete%20A">Athlete A</a>" (2020). "Hoosiers" and "Ringling Bros. Parade Film" (1902) were added to the <a href="National%20Film%20Registry">National Film Registry</a> in 2001 and 2021, respectively.
Indianapolis natives <a href="Jane%20Pauley">Jane Pauley</a> and <a href="David%20Letterman">David Letterman</a> launched their <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmy Award</a>-winning broadcasting careers in local media, Pauley with <a href="WISH-TV">WISH-TV</a> and Letterman with <a href="WTHR">WTHR</a>, respectively. Television programs that have shot on location in the city include "<a href="Aerial%20America">Aerial America</a>", "<a href="American%20Ninja%20Warrior">American Ninja Warrior</a>", "<a href="Cops%20%28TV%20series%29">Cops</a>", "<a href="The%20Dead%20Files">The Dead Files</a>", "<a href="Diners%2C%20Drive-Ins%20and%20Dives">Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives</a>", "<a href="Gaycation%20%28TV%20series%29">Gaycation</a>", "<a href="Ghost%20Hunters%20%28TV%20series%29">Ghost Hunters</a>", "<a href="Late%20Night%20with%20Jimmy%20Fallon">Late Night with Jimmy Fallon</a>", "<a href="Man%20v.%20Food">Man v. Food</a>", "<a href="Say%20I%20Do">Say I Do</a>", "<a href="Today%20%28American%20TV%20program%29">Today</a>", "<a href="What%20Would%20You%20Do%3F%20%282008%20TV%20program%29">What Would You Do?</a>", and "<a href="Parks%20and%20Recreation">Parks and Recreation</a>", notably the eponymous episode "<a href="Indianapolis%20%28Parks%20and%20Recreation%29">Indianapolis</a>." <a href="HGTV">HGTV</a>'s "<a href="Good%20Bones%20%28TV%20series%29">Good Bones</a>" is filmed entirely in the city.
Annual <a href="film%20festival">film festival</a>s held in Indianapolis include the Circle City Film Festival, <a href="Heartland%20Film%20Festival">Heartland Film Festival</a>, <a href="Indianapolis%20International%20Film%20Festival">Indianapolis International Film Festival</a>, <a href="Indianapolis%20Jewish%20Film%20Festival">Indianapolis Jewish Film Festival</a>, and Indianapolis LGBT Film Festival. Founded in 2018, the Indy Shorts International Film Festival is one of 34 film festivals in the world used to qualify for the Academy Awards.
Film Indy was established in 2016 to support local visual artists, filmmakers, and aspiring filmmakers; recruit film and television-related marketing opportunities to the region, and provide resources for producers interested in filming in the city.
