Since 2016, more than 350 film and media projects have been produced in the Indianapolis region with a collective economic impact of $24.1 million and the creation of 1,900 local jobs.
Sports.
Two <a href="Major%20professional%20sports%20leagues%20in%20the%20United%20States%20and%20Canada">major league</a> sports teams are based in Indianapolis: the <a href="Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) and the <a href="Indiana%20Pacers">Indiana Pacers</a> of the <a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a> (NBA).
Originally the <a href="Baltimore%20Colts">Baltimore Colts</a>, the franchise has been based in Indianapolis since <a href="Baltimore%20Colts%20relocation%20to%20Indianapolis">relocating</a> in 1984. The Colts' tenure in Indianapolis has produced 11 division championships, two conference championships, and two <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> appearances. <a href="Quarterback">Quarterback</a> <a href="Peyton%20Manning">Peyton Manning</a> led the team to win <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLI">Super Bowl XLI</a> in the <a href="2006%20NFL%20season">2006 NFL season</a>. <a href="Lucas%20Oil%20Stadium">Lucas Oil Stadium</a> replaced the team's first home, the <a href="RCA%20Dome">RCA Dome</a>, in 2008.
Founded in 1967, the <a href="Indiana%20Pacers">Indiana Pacers</a> began in the <a href="American%20Basketball%20Association">American Basketball Association</a> (ABA), joining the NBA when the leagues <a href="ABA-NBA%20merger">merged</a> in 1976. Before joining the NBA, the Pacers won three division titles and three championships (<a href="1970%20ABA%20Playoffs">1970</a>, <a href="1972%20ABA%20Playoffs">1972</a>, <a href="1973%20ABA%20Playoffs">1973</a>). Since the merger, the Pacers have won one conference title and six division titles, most recently in <a href="2013%E2%80%9314%20NBA%20season">2014</a>.
Founded in 2000, the <a href="Indiana%20Fever">Indiana Fever</a> of the <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Basketball%20Association">Women's National Basketball Association</a> (WNBA) have won three conference titles and one championship in <a href="2012%20WNBA%20season">2012</a>. The Indians have won 25 division titles, 14 league titles, and seven championships, most recently in 2000. Carroll Track & Soccer Stadium</a>. <a href="Indy%20Fuel">Indy Fuel</a> of the <a href="ECHL">ECHL</a> was founded in 2014 and plays at <a href="Indiana%20Farmers%20Coliseum">Indiana Farmers Coliseum</a>.
<a href="Butler%20University">Butler University</a> and <a href="Indiana%20University%20%E2%80%93%20Purdue%20University%20Indianapolis">IUPUI</a> are <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">NCAA</a> <a href="Division%20I%20%28NCAA%29">Division I</a> schools based in the city. The <a href="Butler%20Bulldogs">Butler Bulldogs</a> compete in the <a href="Big%20East%20Conference">Big East Conference</a>, except for <a href="Butler%20Bulldogs%20football">Butler Bulldogs football</a>, which plays in the <a href="Pioneer%20Football%20League">Pioneer Football League</a> <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I%20Football%20Championship%20Subdivision">FCS</a>. The <a href="Butler%20Bulldogs%20men%27s%20basketball">Butler Bulldogs men's basketball</a> team were runners-up in the <a href="2010%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Championship%20Game">2010</a> and <a href="2011%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Championship%20Game">2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship Game</a>s. The <a href="IUPUI%20Jaguars">IUPUI Jaguars</a> compete in the <a href="Horizon%20League">Horizon League</a>.
Traditionally, Indianapolis's <a href="Hinkle%20Fieldhouse">Hinkle Fieldhouse</a> was the hub for <a href="Hoosier%20Hysteria">Hoosier Hysteria</a>, a general excitement for the game of basketball throughout the state, specifically the <a href="Indiana%20High%20School%20Boys%20Basketball%20Tournament">Indiana High School Boys Basketball Tournament</a>. Hinkle, a <a href="National%20Historic%20Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a>, was opened in 1928 as the world's largest basketball arena, with seating for 15,000. It is regarded as "Indiana's Basketball Cathedral". Perhaps the most notable game was the <a href="1954%20Milan%20High%20School%20basketball%20team">1954 state championship</a>, which inspired the critically acclaimed 1986 film, "<a href="Hoosiers%20%28film%29">Hoosiers</a>".
Indianapolis has been called the "Amateur Sports Capital of the World". The <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">National Collegiate Athletic Association</a> (NCAA), the main governing body for U.S. collegiate sports, and the <a href="National%20Federation%20of%20State%20High%20School%20Associations">National Federation of State High School Associations</a> are based in Indianapolis. The city is home to three <a href="List%20of%20NCAA%20conferences">NCAA athletic conferences</a>: the <a href="Horizon%20League">Horizon League</a> (<a href="NCAA%20Division%20I">Division I</a>); the <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Valley%20Conference">Great Lakes Valley Conference</a> (<a href="NCAA%20Division%20II">Division II</a>); and the <a href="Heartland%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Conference">Heartland Collegiate Athletic Conference</a> (<a href="NCAA%20Division%20III">Division III</a>). Indianapolis is also home to three national sport governing bodies, as recognized by the <a href="United%20States%20Olympic%20%26amp%3B%20Paralympic%20Committee">U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee</a>: <a href="USA%20Gymnastics">USA Gymnastics</a>; <a href="USA%20Diving">USA Diving</a>; and <a href="USA%20Track%20%26amp%3B%20Field">USA Track & Field</a>.
Indianapolis hosts numerous sporting events annually, including the <a href="Circle%20City%20Classic">Circle City Classic</a> (1983–present), <a href="NFL%20Scouting%20Combine">NFL Scouting Combine</a> (1987–present), and <a href="Big%20Ten%20Football%20Championship%20Game">Big Ten Football Championship Game</a> (2011–present). Indianapolis is tied with <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> for having hosted the second most <a href="NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Championship">NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship</a>s (<a href="1980%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">1980</a>, <a href="1991%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">1991</a>, <a href="1997%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">1997</a>, <a href="2000%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2000</a>, <a href="2006%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2006</a>, <a href="2010%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2010</a>, <a href="2015%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2015</a>, and <a href="2021%20NCAA%20Division%20I%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">2021</a>). The city will host the men's Final Four next in 2026. The city has also hosted three <a href="NCAA%20Women%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Championship">NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Championship</a>s (<a href="2005%20NCAA%20Women%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2005</a>, <a href="2011%20NCAA%20Women%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2011</a>, and <a href="2016%20NCAA%20Men%27s%20Division%20I%20Basketball%20Tournament">2016</a>). Notable past events include the <a href="NBA%20All-Star%20Game">NBA All-Star Game</a> (<a href="1985%20NBA%20All-Star%20Game">1985</a>), <a href="1987%20Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games X</a> (1987), <a href="US%20Open%20Series">US Open Series</a> <a href="Indianapolis%20Tennis%20Championships">Indianapolis Tennis Championships</a> (1988–2009), <a href="World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">World Artistic Gymnastics Championships</a> (<a href="1991%20World%20Artistic%20Gymnastics%20Championships">1991</a>), <a href="WrestleMania%20VIII">WrestleMania VIII</a> (1992), <a href="World%20Rowing%20Championships">World Rowing Championships</a> (<a href="1994%20World%20Rowing%20Championships">1994</a>), <a href="World%20Police%20and%20Fire%20Games">World Police and Fire Games</a> (2001), <a href="FIBA%20Basketball%20World%20Cup">FIBA Basketball World Cup</a> (<a href="2002%20FIBA%20World%20Championship">2002</a>), <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVI">Super Bowl XLVI</a> (2012) and the <a href="College%20Football%20Playoff%20National%20Championship">College Football Playoff National Championship</a> (<a href="2022%20College%20Football%20Playoff%20National%20Championship">2022</a>).
Indianapolis is home to the <a href="OneAmerica%20500%20Festival%20Mini-Marathon">OneAmerica 500 Festival Mini-Marathon</a>, the largest <a href="half%20marathon">half marathon</a> and seventh largest running event in the U.S. The mini-marathon is held the first weekend of May as part of the 500 Festival, leading up to the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>. , it had sold out for 12 consecutive years, with 35,000 participants. Held in autumn, the <a href="Monumental%20Marathon">Monumental Marathon</a> is also among the largest in the U.S., with nearly 14,000 entrants in 2015.
Motorsports.
Indianapolis is a major center for <a href="motorsport">motorsport</a>s. Two <a href="auto%20racing">auto racing</a> sanctioning bodies are headquartered in the city (<a href="INDYCAR">INDYCAR</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Auto%20Club">United States Auto Club</a>) along with more than 500 motorsports companies and racing teams, employing some 10,000 people in the region. Indianapolis is a <a href="metonymy">metonym</a> for auto racing, having inspired the name "Indy car," used for both the competition and type of car used in it.
Since 1911, <a href="Indianapolis%20Motor%20Speedway">Indianapolis Motor Speedway</a> (IMS) (in the <a href="enclave">enclave</a> of <a href="Speedway%2C%20Indiana">Speedway</a>) has been the site of the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>, an <a href="American%20open-wheel%20car%20racing">open-wheel</a> automobile race held annually on <a href="Memorial%20Day">Memorial Day</a> weekend. Considered part of the <a href="Triple%20Crown%20of%20Motorsport">Triple Crown of Motorsport</a>, the Indianapolis 500 is the world's largest single-day sporting event, hosting more than 257,000 permanent seats. Since 1994, IMS has hosted one of <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a>'s highest attended events, the <a href="NASCAR%20Cup%20Series">NASCAR Cup Series</a> <a href="Brickyard%20400">Brickyard 400</a>. IMS has also hosted the <a href="NASCAR%20Xfinity%20Series">NASCAR Xfinity Series</a> <a href="Pennzoil%20150">Pennzoil 150</a> since 2012 and the <a href="IndyCar%20Series">IndyCar Series</a> <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20Indianapolis">Grand Prix of Indianapolis</a> since 2014. From 2000 to 2007, the circuit hosted <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> at the facility's road course.
<a href="Lucas%20Oil%20Indianapolis%20Raceway%20Park">Lucas Oil Indianapolis Raceway Park</a>, in nearby <a href="Brownsburg%2C%20Indiana">Brownsburg</a>, is home to the <a href="National%20Hot%20Rod%20Association">National Hot Rod Association</a> (NHRA) <a href="NHRA%20U.S.%20Nationals">U.S. Nationals</a>, the most prestigious <a href="drag%20racing">drag racing</a> event in the world, held annually each <a href="Labor%20Day">Labor Day</a> weekend.
Government and politics.
Indianapolis—officially the City of Indianapolis and <a href="Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Marion County</a>—has a <a href="consolidated%20city-county">consolidated city-county</a> form of government, a status it has held since 1970 under <a href="Indiana%20Code">Indiana Code</a>'s <a href="Unigov">Unigov</a> provision. Many functions of the city and county governments are consolidated, though some remain separate. The city has a <a href="Mayor%E2%80%93council%20government%23Strong-mayor%20form">strong mayor–council</a> form of government overseeing six administrative departments. Marion County also contains some 60 taxing units, nine separate <a href="civil%20township">civil township</a> governments, and seven special-purpose <a href="municipally%20owned%20corporation">municipal corporations</a>.
The executive branch is headed by an elected mayor, who serves as the chief executive of both the city and county. <a href="Joe%20Hogsett">Joe Hogsett</a>, a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>, is the 49th mayor of Indianapolis. <a href="Indianapolis%20City-County%20Council">Indianapolis City-County Council</a> is the legislative body and consists of 25 members, all of whom represent geographic districts. The mayor and council members are elected to unlimited four-year terms. The judicial branch consists of a circuit court and superior court with four divisions and 32 judges. The three branches, along with most local government departments, are based in the <a href="City-County%20Building%20%28Indianapolis%29">City-County Building</a>. Each of the county's nine civil townships elects its own <a href="Indiana%20township%20trustee">township trustee</a>, three-member board, assessor, and a constable and small claims court judge, all of whom serve four-year terms.
The municipal budget for 2022 was $1.3 billion. The city-county government employs about 8,000 full-time employees.
Since its move from <a href="Corydon%2C%20Indiana">Corydon</a> in 1825, Indianapolis has served as the <a href="List%20of%20capitals%20in%20the%20United%20States">capital</a> and seat of Indiana's state government. The <a href="Indiana%20Statehouse">Indiana Statehouse</a> houses the executive, legislative, and judicial branches of state government, including the offices of the <a href="Governor%20of%20Indiana">Governor of Indiana</a> and <a href="Lieutenant%20Governor%20of%20Indiana">Lieutenant Governor of Indiana</a>, the <a href="Indiana%20General%20Assembly">Indiana General Assembly</a>, and the <a href="Indiana%20Supreme%20Court">Indiana Supreme Court</a>. Most state departments and agencies are in the <a href="Indiana%20Government%20Center%20North">Indiana Government Center</a> complex. The <a href="Indiana%20Governor%27s%20Residence">Indiana Governor's Residence</a> is on <a href="Meridian%20Street%20%28Indianapolis%29">Meridian Street</a> in the <a href="Butler-Tarkington%2C%20Indianapolis">Butler–Tarkington</a> neighborhood, about north of downtown.
Most of Indianapolis is within <a href="Indiana%27s%207th%20congressional%20district">Indiana's 7th congressional district</a>, represented by Democrat <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Carson">André Carson</a>, while the northern fifth is part of <a href="Indiana%27s%205th%20congressional%20district">Indiana's 5th congressional district</a>, represented by Republican <a href="Victoria%20Spartz">Victoria Spartz</a>. The <a href="Birch%20Bayh%20Federal%20Building%20and%20United%20States%20Courthouse">Birch Bayh Federal Building and United States Courthouse</a> houses the <a href="United%20States%20District%20Court%20for%20the%20Southern%20District%20of%20Indiana">United States District Court for the Southern District of Indiana</a>. Most federal field offices are located in the <a href="Minton-Capehart%20Federal%20Building">Minton-Capehart Federal Building</a>. The <a href="Defense%20Finance%20and%20Accounting%20Service">Defense Finance and Accounting Service</a>, an agency of the <a href="U.S.%20Department%20of%20Defense">U.S. Department of Defense</a>, is headquartered in nearby <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Indiana">Lawrence</a>.
Politics.
Until fairly recently, Indianapolis was considered one of the most <a href="Conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservative</a> major cities in the U.S. According to 2014 research published in the "<a href="American%20Political%20Science%20Review">American Political Science Review</a>", the city's policy preferences are less conservative than the national mean when compared with other large U.S. cities. While Indianapolis as a whole leans Democratic, the southern third of the city, consisting of the townships of <a href="Decatur%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Decatur</a>, <a href="Perry%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Perry</a> and <a href="Franklin%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Franklin</a>, has a Republican lean.
<a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a>s held the mayor's office for 32 years (1967–1999), and controlled the City-County Council from its inception in 1970 to 2003. In the <a href="2000%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2000 United States presidential election</a>, Marion County voters narrowly selected <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a> over <a href="Al%20Gore">Al Gore</a> by a margin of 1.3%, but voted in favor of <a href="John%20Kerry">John Kerry</a> by a margin of 1.9% in the <a href="2004%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2004 United States presidential election</a>. Presidential election results have increasingly favored Democrats, with Marion County voters selecting <a href="Joe%20Biden">Joe Biden</a> over <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a> in the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2020 United States presidential election</a>, 63.3–34.3%. Incumbent mayor <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a> <a href="Joe%20Hogsett">Joe Hogsett</a> faced Republican State Senator <a href="Jim%20Merritt%20%28politician%29">Jim Merritt</a> and <a href="Libertarian%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Libertarian</a> Doug McNaughton in the <a href="2019%20Indianapolis%20mayoral%20election">2019 Indianapolis mayoral election</a>. Hogsett was elected to a second term, with 72% of the vote. The <a href="2019%20Indianapolis%20City-County%20Council%20election">2019 City-County Council elections</a> expanded Democratic control of the council, flipping six seats to hold a 20–5 <a href="supermajority">supermajority</a> over Republicans.
Public safety.
Police and law enforcement.
Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department (IMPD) is the primary <a href="law%20enforcement%20agency">law enforcement agency</a> for the city of Indianapolis. IMPD's jurisdiction covers Marion County, excluding the municipalities of <a href="Beech%20Grove%2C%20Indiana">Beech Grove</a>, <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Indiana">Lawrence</a>, <a href="Southport%2C%20Indiana">Southport</a>, <a href="Speedway%2C%20Indiana">Speedway</a>, and jurisdiction of the <a href="Indianapolis%20Airport%20Authority%20Police%20Department">Indianapolis Airport Authority Police Department</a>. IMPD was established in 2007 through a merger between the <a href="Indianapolis%20Police%20Department">Indianapolis Police Department</a> and the Marion County Sheriff's Office Law Enforcement Division. The Marion County Sheriff's Office manages Marion County Jails I and II. In 2020, IMPD had 1,700 sworn police personnel and 250 civilian employees across six districts.
Until 2019, annual criminal homicide numbers had grown each year since 2011, reaching record highs from 2015 to 2018. With 144 criminal homicides, 2015 surpassed 1998 as the year with the most murder investigations in the city. With 159 criminal homicides, 2018 stands as the most violent year on record in the city. <a href="Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation">FBI</a> data showed a 7 percent increase in violent crimes committed in Indianapolis, outpacing the rest of the state and country. Law enforcement has blamed increased violence on a combination of root causes, including poverty, substance abuse, and mental illness.
Fire department and emergency medical services.
Indianapolis Fire Department (IFD) provides fire protection and rescue services as the primary emergency response agency for of Marion County. IFD provides <a href="mutual%20aid%20%28emergency%20services%29">mutual aid</a> to the excluded municipalities of <a href="Beech%20Grove%2C%20Indiana">Beech Grove</a>, <a href="Lawrence%2C%20Indiana">Lawrence</a>, and <a href="Speedway%2C%20Indiana">Speedway</a>, as well as <a href="Decatur%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Decatur</a>, <a href="Pike%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Pike</a>, and <a href="Wayne%20Township%2C%20Marion%20County%2C%20Indiana">Wayne</a> townships which have retained their own fire departments. The fire district comprises seven geographic battalions with 43 fire stations. Some 1,200 firefighters respond to more than 161,000 incidents annually. IFD directs operations for Indiana Task-Force One (IN-TF1), one of 28 <a href="FEMA%20Urban%20Search%20and%20Rescue%20Task%20Force">FEMA Urban Search and Rescue Task Force</a> teams in the U.S.
Indianapolis Emergency Medical Services (IEMS) is the largest provider of pre-hospital medical care in Indiana and responds to 120,000 emergency dispatch calls annually. Similar to IFD, the agency's coverage area excludes Decatur, Pike, and Wayne townships, and the town of Speedway.
Education.
Primary and secondary education.
Nine <a href="K%E2%80%9312">K–12</a> public school districts serve Indianapolis residents, the largest being <a href="Indianapolis%20Public%20Schools">Indianapolis Public Schools</a> (IPS). The other eight public school districts are <a href="Franklin%20Township%20Community%20School%20Corporation">Franklin Township Community School Corporation</a>, <a href="Metropolitan%20School%20District%20of%20Decatur%20Township">Metropolitan School District of Decatur Township</a>, <a href="Metropolitan%20School%20District%20of%20Lawrence%20Township">Metropolitan School District of Lawrence Township</a>, <a href="Metropolitan%20School%20District%20of%20Pike%20Township">Metropolitan School District of Pike Township</a>, <a href="Metropolitan%20School%20District%20of%20Warren%20Township">Metropolitan School District of Warren Township</a>, <a href="Metropolitan%20School%20District%20of%20Washington%20Township">Metropolitan School District of Washington Township</a>, <a href="Metropolitan%20School%20District%20of%20Wayne%20Township">Metropolitan School District of Wayne Township</a>, and <a href="Perry%20Township%20Schools">Perry Township Schools</a>. Two state-supported <a href="Boarding%20school">residential school</a>s located in the city include the <a href="Indiana%20School%20for%20the%20Blind%20and%20Visually%20Impaired">Indiana School for the Blind and Visually Impaired</a> and <a href="Indiana%20School%20for%20the%20Deaf">Indiana School for the Deaf</a>.
IPS has an annual enrollment of about 32,000 students attending 59 schools. In 2015, IPS began contracting with charter organizations and nonprofit school managers to operate failing district schools as innovation schools. About 37% of IPS students are enrolled in 20 innovation schools, which are run independently but accountable to the Board of School Commissioners, with the remaining 63% of students attending 39 neighborhood or magnet schools. About 18,000 students are enrolled in tuition-free Mayor-Sponsored Charter Schools (MSCS), as authorized by the Indianapolis Mayor's Office of Education Innovation and Indianapolis Charter School Board.
There are dozens of private, parochial, and independent charter schools operating throughout the city. <a href="Catholic%20schools%20in%20the%20United%20States">Catholic</a> and Christian primary and secondary schools are most prevalent.
Higher education.
Indianapolis' higher education landscape is dominated by <a href="Indiana%20University%20%E2%80%93%20Purdue%20University%20Indianapolis">Indiana University – Purdue University Indianapolis</a> (IUPUI), a <a href="public%20university">public university</a> formed in 1969 after the branch campuses of <a href="Indiana%20University">Indiana University</a> and <a href="Purdue%20University%20system">Purdue University</a> merged. IUPUI is classified as an <a href="urban%20university">urban</a> <a href="List%20of%20research%20universities%20in%20the%20United%20States">research university</a>, enrolling 30,000 students in 450 undergraduate, graduate, and professional programs offered by 17 schools. Notable schools include the <a href="Herron%20School%20of%20Art%20and%20Design">Herron School of Art and Design</a>, <a href="Indiana%20University%20Robert%20H.%20McKinney%20School%20of%20Law">Robert H. McKinney School of Law</a>, <a href="Kelley%20School%20of%20Business">Kelley School of Business</a>, and the <a href="Indiana%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">Indiana University School of Medicine</a>, among the largest medical schools in the U.S.
Indiana's statewide <a href="community%20college">community college</a> system, <a href="Ivy%20Tech%20Community%20College%20of%20Indiana">Ivy Tech</a>, enrolls some 21,000 full-time students at two full-service campuses, one learning site, and the Automotive Technology Center in the Indianapolis service area. Other public institutions with <a href="satellite%20campus">satellite campus</a>es in the city include <a href="Ball%20State%20University">Ball State University</a>'s <a href="R.%20Wayne%20Estopinal%20College%20of%20Architecture%20and%20Planning">R. Wayne Estopinal College of Architecture and Planning</a> and <a href="Vincennes%20University">Vincennes University</a>.
Two <a href="secularity">secular</a> <a href="private%20universities">private universities</a> are based in Indianapolis. Founded in 1855, <a href="Butler%20University">Butler University</a> serves an enrollment of about 5,000 from its <a href="Butler%E2%80%93Tarkington%2C%20Indianapolis">Butler–Tarkington</a> campus. <a href="Martin%20University">Martin University</a>, Indiana's only <a href="Minority-serving%20institution">Predominantly Black Institution</a>, was founded in 1977 and is located in the <a href="Martindale%E2%80%93Brightwood%2C%20Indianapolis">Martindale–Brightwood</a> neighborhood. <a href="Indiana%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Indiana Tech</a> maintains a branch campus in the city. Two <a href="seminaries">seminaries</a> are based in the city: <a href="Bishop%20Simon%20Brut%C3%A9%20College%20Seminary">Bishop Simon Bruté College Seminary</a> and <a href="Christian%20Theological%20Seminary">Christian Theological Seminary</a>. Three religiously affiliated universities based in the city are <a href="Indiana%20Bible%20College">Indiana Bible College</a>, <a href="University%20of%20Indianapolis">University of Indianapolis</a>, and <a href="Marian%20University%20%28Indiana%29">Marian University</a>. <a href="Indiana%20Wesleyan%20University">Indiana Wesleyan University</a> operates a satellite campus in Indianapolis.
More than 40 collegiate <a href="fraternities%20and%20sororities">fraternities and sororities</a> are headquartered in the Indianapolis metropolitan area, the largest concentration in North America.
Libraries.
Founded in 1873, the <a href="Indianapolis%20Public%20Library">Indianapolis Public Library</a> includes <a href="Indianapolis%20Public%20Library%23Central%20Library">Central Library</a> and 24 branches throughout Marion County. Central Library houses a number of special collections, including the Center for Black Literature & Culture, the <a href="Chris%20Gonzalez%20Library%20and%20Archives">Chris Gonzalez LGBT Collection</a>, and the <a href="Nina%20Mason%20Pulliam%20Indianapolis%20Special%20Collections%20Room">Nina Mason Pulliam Indianapolis Special Collections Room</a>. The public library serves about 280,000 cardholders with a circulation of nearly 10 million materials annually.
Media.

The "Star" is owned by <a href="Gannett%20Company">Gannett Company</a>, with a daily circulation of 127,064. The "<a href="Indianapolis%20News">Indianapolis News</a>" was the city's daily evening newspaper and oldest print media, published from 1869 to 1999. Notable weeklies include "<a href="NUVO%20%28newspaper%29">NUVO</a>", an <a href="alternative%20weekly">alternative weekly</a> newspaper, the "<a href="Indianapolis%20Recorder">Indianapolis Recorder</a>", a weekly newspaper serving the local <a href="African%20American">African American</a> community, the "<a href="Indianapolis%20Business%20Journal">Indianapolis Business Journal</a>", reporting on local real estate news, and the "<a href="The%20Southside%20Times">Southside Times</a>". "<a href="Indianapolis%20Monthly">Indianapolis Monthly</a>" is the city's monthly lifestyle publication.

Infrastructure.
Transportation.
Indianapolis's transportation infrastructure comprises a complex network that includes a local public bus system, several private intercity bus providers, <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a> passenger rail service, four freight rail lines, four <a href="List%20of%20Interstate%20Highways">primary</a> and two <a href="List%20of%20auxiliary%20Interstate%20Highways">auxiliary</a> <a href="Interstate%20Highway%20System">Interstate Highways</a>, two airports, a heliport, bikeshare system, of bike lanes, and of trails and greenways. Private <a href="ridesharing%20companies">ridesharing companies</a> <a href="Lyft">Lyft</a> and <a href="Uber">Uber</a> as well as <a href="taxicabs">taxicabs</a> operate in the city. After negotiations with city officials, <a href="Bird%20%28company%29">Bird</a> and <a href="Lime%20%28transportation%20company%29">Lime</a> electric <a href="scooter-sharing%20system">scooter-sharing</a> launched in September 2018.
Absent a comprehensive regional public transit system in combination with <a href="urban%20sprawl">urban sprawl</a>, Indianapolis residents drive more vehicle miles per capita than any other U.S. city. According to the 2016 <a href="American%20Community%20Survey">American Community Survey</a>, 83.7% of working residents in the city commuted by driving alone, 8.4% carpooled, 1.5% used public transportation, and 1.8% walked. About 1.5% used all other forms of transportation, including taxicab, motorcycle, and bicycle. About 3.1% of working city residents worked at home. In 2015, 10.5 percent of Indianapolis households lacked a car, which decreased to 8.7 percent in 2016, the same as the national average in that year. Indianapolis averaged 1.63 cars per household in 2016, compared to a national average of 1.8.
Streets and highways.
Four primary Interstate Highways intersect the city: <a href="Interstate%2065%20in%20Indiana">Interstate 65</a>, <a href="Interstate%2069%20in%20Indiana">Interstate 69</a>, <a href="Interstate%2070%20in%20Indiana">Interstate 70</a>, and <a href="Interstate%2074%20in%20Indiana">Interstate 74</a>. The metropolitan area also has two auxiliary Interstate Highways: a <a href="beltway">beltway</a> (<a href="Interstate%20465">Interstate 465</a>) and <a href="connector%20%28road%29">connector</a> (<a href="Interstate%20865">Interstate 865</a>). A $3 billion expansion project to extend Interstate 69 from <a href="Evansville%2C%20Indiana">Evansville</a> to Indianapolis is in progress. The <a href="Indiana%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Indiana Department of Transportation</a> manages all Interstates, <a href="United%20States%20Numbered%20Highway%20System">U.S. Highways</a>, and <a href="List%20of%20state%20roads%20in%20Indiana">Indiana State Roads</a> within the city. The city's Department of Public Works maintains about of street, in addition to 540 bridges, alleys, sidewalks, and curbs.
Walking and bicycling.
Reliance on driving has impacted the city's <a href="walkability">walkability</a>, with <a href="Walk%20Score">Walk Score</a> ranking Indianapolis as one of the least walkable large cities in the U.S. However, city officials have increased investments in bicycle and pedestrian infrastructure in recent years. About of trails and greenways form the core of the city's active transportation network, connecting into of on-street bike lanes. Trails and greenways include the <a href="Fall%20Creek%20Trail">Fall Creek Greenway</a>, <a href="Pleasant%20Run%20Greenway">Pleasant Run Greenway</a>, and <a href="Monon%20Trail">Monon Trail</a>. The Monon is notable as a <a href="rail%20trail">rail trail</a> and part of the <a href="United%20States%20Bicycle%20Route%20System">United States Bicycle Route System</a>. The privately managed provides of separated bike and pedestrian corridors and operates <a href="Indiana%20Pacers%20Bikeshare">Indiana Pacers Bikeshare</a>, the city's <a href="bicycle-sharing%20system">bicycle-sharing system</a>, consisting of 525 bicycles at 50 stations. Indianapolis is designated a "Bronze Level" Bicycle Friendly Community by the <a href="League%20of%20American%20Bicyclists">League of American Bicyclists</a>.
Airports.
<a href="Indianapolis%20International%20Airport">Indianapolis International Airport</a> (<a href="IATA%20airport%20code">IATA</a>: IND) sits on approximately southwest of downtown Indianapolis. IND is the busiest airport in the state, serving more than 9.4 million passengers annually. Completed in 2008, the Colonel H. Weir Cook Terminal contains two concourses and 40 gates, connecting to 51 nonstop domestic and international destinations and averaging 145 daily departures. As home to the second largest <a href="FedEx%20Express">FedEx Express</a> hub in the world, IND ranks among the <a href="List%20of%20the%20busiest%20airports%20in%20the%20United%20States%2310%20busiest%20airports%20in%20the%20U.S.%20by%20total%20cargo%20throughput%20%282017%29">ten busiest U.S. airports</a> in terms of air cargo throughput. The <a href="Indianapolis%20Airport%20Authority">Indianapolis Airport Authority</a> is a municipal corporation that oversees operations at five additional airports in the region, two of which are located in the city: <a href="Eagle%20Creek%20Airpark">Eagle Creek Airpark</a> (<a href="Federal%20Aviation%20Administration">FAA</a> <a href="location%20identifier">LID</a>:EYE), a <a href="relief%20airport">relief airport</a> for IND, and the <a href="Indianapolis%20Downtown%20Heliport">Indianapolis Downtown Heliport</a> (IATA: 8A4).
Public transit.
The Indianapolis Public Transportation Corporation, <a href="trade%20name">doing business as</a> <a href="IndyGo">IndyGo</a>, operates the city's <a href="public%20transport%20bus%20service">public bus system</a>. In 2016, the <a href="Julia%20M.%20Carson%20Transit%20Center">Julia M. Carson Transit Center</a> opened, the downtown hub for 27 of its 31 bus routes and operating 9.2 million passenger trips. In 2017, <a href="Indianapolis%20City-County%20Council">City-County Council</a> approved a voter referendum increasing Marion County's income tax to help fund IndyGo's first major system expansion since its 1975 founding. The Marion County Transit Plan outlines proposed system improvements, including three <a href="bus%20rapid%20transit">bus rapid transit</a> (BRT) lines, new buses, sidewalks, and bus shelters, extended hours and weekend schedules, and a 70% increase in service hours on all existing local routes. Phase I of IndyGo's <a href="Red%20Line%20%28IndyGo%29">Red Line</a>, the first of the three planned BRT lines, began service on September 1, 2019. The Central Indiana Regional Transportation Authority (CIRTA) is a quasi-governmental agency that organizes regional <a href="carpool">car</a> and <a href="vanpools">vanpools</a> and operates three public workforce connectors from Indianapolis to employment centers in <a href="Plainfield%2C%20Indiana">Plainfield</a> and <a href="Whitestown%2C%20Indiana">Whitestown</a>.
Intercity bus.
Several private <a href="intercity%20bus%20service">intercity bus service</a> providers stop in the city. <a href="Greyhound%20Lines">Greyhound Lines</a> operates a bus terminal at Union Station and stop at Indianapolis International Airport's Ground Transportation Center. <a href="Barons%20Bus%20Lines">Barons Bus Lines</a>, <a href="Burlington%20Trailways">Burlington Trailways</a>, and Miller Transportation's Hoosier Ride also stop at Greyhound's Union Station bus terminal. <a href="Megabus%20%28North%20America%29">Megabus</a> stops at the corner of North Alabama Street and East Market Street near the <a href="Indianapolis%20City%20Market">Indianapolis City Market</a>. GO Express Travel manages two shuttle services: GO Green Express between downtown Indianapolis and the Indianapolis International Airport and Campus Commute between <a href="Indiana%20University%20-%20Purdue%20University%20Indianapolis">IUPUI</a> and <a href="Indiana%20University%20Bloomington">Indiana University Bloomington</a>. <a href="OurBus">OurBus</a> began daily service between Indianapolis and Chicago, with stops in <a href="Zionsville%2C%20Indiana">Zionsville</a> and <a href="Lafayette%2C%20Indiana">Lafayette</a>, filling a gap left after Amtrak's "<a href="Hoosier%20State%20%28train%29">Hoosier State</a>" was discontinued in July 2019.
Rail.
<a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>, the national passenger rail system, provides <a href="inter-city%20rail">inter-city rail</a> service to Indianapolis via <a href="Indianapolis%20Union%20Station">Union Station</a>, serving about 30,000 passengers in 2015. The "<a href="Cardinal%20%28passenger%20train%29">Cardinal</a>" makes three weekly trips between <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> and <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>. Amtrak's <a href="Beech%20Grove%20Shops">Beech Grove Shops</a>, in the enclave of <a href="Beech%20Grove%2C%20Indiana">Beech Grove</a>, serve as its primary heavy maintenance and overhaul facility, while the Indianapolis Distribution Center is the company's largest material and supply terminal.
About of freight rail lines converge in the city, including one <a href="Railroad%20classes%23Class%20I">Class I</a> railroad (<a href="CSX%20Transportation">CSX Transportation</a>), one <a href="Railroad%20classes%23Class%20II">Class II</a> railroad (<a href="Indiana%20Rail%20Road%20Company">Indiana Rail Road Company</a>), and two <a href="shortline%20railroad">shortline railroad</a>s (<a href="Indiana%20Southern%20Railroad">Indiana Southern Railroad</a> and <a href="Louisville%20and%20Indiana%20Railroad">Louisville and Indiana Railroad</a>). Indianapolis is a hub for CSX Transportation, home to its division headquarters, an <a href="intermodal%20freight%20transport">intermodal terminal</a>, and <a href="classification%20yard">classification yard</a> in the suburb of <a href="Avon%2C%20Indiana">Avon</a>.
Healthcare.
Health & Hospital Corporation of Marion County, a municipal corporation, was formed in 1951 to manage the city's public health facilities and programs, including the Marion County Public Health Department and Eskenazi Health. Eskenazi Health operates 11 <a href="primary%20care">primary care</a> centers across the city, including its flagship medical center, <a href="Sidney%20%26amp%3B%20Lois%20Eskenazi%20Hospital">Sidney & Lois Eskenazi Hospital</a>. The hospital includes an <a href="Level%20I%20Trauma%20Center">Adult Level I Trauma Center</a>, 315 beds, and 275 exam rooms, annually serving about 1 million outpatients. The <a href="Veterans%20Health%20Administration">Veterans Health Administration</a>'s Richard L. Roudebush VA Medical Center is Indiana's <a href="tertiary%20referral%20hospital">tertiary referral hospital</a> for former armed services personnel, treating more than 60,000 veterans annually. The Indiana Family and Social Services Administration oversees the <a href="NeuroDiagnostic%20Institute">NeuroDiagnostic Institute</a>, a 159-bed <a href="psychiatric%20hospital">psychiatric hospital</a> which replaced <a href="Indianapolis%20Veterans%20Administration%20Hospital">Larue D. Carter Memorial Hospital</a> in 2019.
<a href="Indiana%20University%20Health">Indiana University Health</a>, a nonprofit <a href="hospital%20network">hospital network</a>, operates three <a href="Teaching%20hospitals%20in%20the%20United%20States">teaching hospital</a>s in Indianapolis: <a href="Indiana%20University%20Hospital">University Hospital</a>, <a href="Indiana%20University%20Health%20Methodist%20Hospital">Methodist Hospital</a>, and <a href="Riley%20Hospital%20for%20Children%20at%20Indiana%20University%20Health">Riley Hospital for Children</a>. The medical centers are anchored by the <a href="Indiana%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">Indiana University School of Medicine</a>'s principal research and education campus, the largest <a href="allopathic%20medicine">allopathic</a> medical school in the U.S. Riley Hospital for Children is among the nation's foremost pediatric health centers, recognized in all ten specialties by "<a href="U.S.%20News%20and%20World%20Report">U.S. News and World Report</a>". The 430-bed facility also contains Indiana's only <a href="Trauma%20center">Pediatric Level I Trauma Center</a>. In 2020, IU Health detailed plans to consolidate University and Methodist hospitals and replace Methodist with a new $1.6 billion medical center, to open in 2026.
Other private and nonprofit healthcare networks with a presence in the city include <a href="Ascension%20%28company%29">Ascension</a> (<a href="St.%20Vincent%20Indianapolis%20Hospital">St. Vincent Indianapolis Hospital</a>); <a href="Franciscan%20Health">Franciscan Health</a> (<a href="Franciscan%20Health%20Indianapolis">Franciscan Health Indianapolis</a>); and Community Health Network (<a href="Community%20Hospital%20East">Community Hospital East</a>, <a href="Community%20Hospital%20North">Community Hospital North</a>, and Community Hospital South).
Utilities.
<a href="AES%20Indiana">AES Indiana</a> (formerly Indianapolis Power & Light) provides 3,000 megawatts of electricity to more than 500,000 customers. Citizens Energy Group, the only public <a href="charitable%20trust">charitable trust</a> formed to operate utilities in the U.S., provides residents with natural gas, water, wastewater, and thermal services. Citizens' <a href="Perry%20K.%20Generating%20Station">Perry K. Generating Station</a> produces steam for the downtown Indianapolis <a href="district%20heating">district heating</a> system, the second largest in the U.S.
The city's water is supplied through four surface water treatment plants, drawing from the <a href="White%20River%20%28Indiana%29">White River</a>, <a href="Fall%20Creek%20%28Indiana%29">Fall Creek</a>, and Eagle Creek; and four pumping stations, providing water supply from groundwater aquifers. Additional water supply is ensured by four reservoirs in the region, the largest being <a href="Geist%20Reservoir">Geist Reservoir</a>.
Eleven solid waste districts are managed by one of three garbage collection providers: the city's Department of Public Works Solid Waste Division, <a href="Republic%20Services">Republic Services</a>, and <a href="Waste%20Management%20%28corporation%29">Waste Management</a>. Residential curbside recycling is a subscription service provided by Republic Services and Ray's Trash Service. Recycling drop-off sites located throughout the city are provided free of charge by the Department of Public Works Solid Waste Division. <a href="Covanta%20Energy">Covanta Energy</a> operates a <a href="waste-to-energy">waste-to-energy</a> plant in the city, processing solid waste for steam production.
